INTRODUCTION
[Beurla]

FOIRM
na n - URRNUIDHEADH

MAR NACH BFETAR baile nō cathair nó teach [L6v]
nó teaghlach do chongbhāil a sdaid nó a n - 2750
inbhe tsona gan riaghail agas gan smacht , is mur sin nach
ēidir Eagluis Dé do chongbhāil suas , nó a neart d ’ fhás , gan
riaghail sbioratālta agas gan smacht eagluise do bheith inte ,
óir is gloine í , agas is córa riaghail do bheith uirre , iná ar
bhaile eile nó ar theaghlach . 2755

Agas mar atáid briathra Dē mar bheathaidh agas mar
anam ag an Eagluis , is mar sin atá an riaghail dhiadha - sa
agas an t - ordughadh eagluise - se mar do bheidīs fēithe ag
fuaidhel agas fīr - cheangal bhall an chuirp - se na h - Eagluise
ré chéile lé h - ordughadh oirrdheirc agas lé nós niamhghlan ; 2760
óir is srian é d ’ fhosdadh na ndroch - dhaoine ó mhí - ghnīomh -
arthuibh do dhēnamh , agas is sbor é do bhrosnughadh na
ndaoine ndīmhaoineach ndo - theagaisg ar a n - adhaidh , agas
asé an smachtughadh - sa slat an Athar atá do ghnáth ullamh
ésgaidh aibēil do chaoin - chear / tughadh na n - olc do - nīthear , [L7]
agas do thabhairt orra ’ na dhiaidh sin a mbeatha do chaith -
eamh a n - eagla agas a n - umhla dhiadha . Agas fós fá dheōidh ,
is ordughadh é do fhāgaibh Dia agā Eagluis , lé ndēnaid
foghlaim a dtoile agas a ngnīomhartha do riaghladh do réir
an ladha diadha , mar atá gach aon aca do dhēnamh theag - 2770

Atáid trí h - adhbhair sbeisialta do - bheir ar Eagluis Dé an
smachtughadh - sa do chur a ngnīomh : an céd - adhbhar 2775
dhīobh , do chum nach áirfidhe lucht droch - ghnīomharthadh
a measg chloinde Dé , do thabhairt náire nó sgandaile dā
n - Athair , mar go mbeith Eagluis Dé ina dīdean agas ina
tearmond do lucht uilc agas aingidheachta ; an dara h -
adhbhar , ar eagla go saileōchaidhe na daoine maithe lé 2780
cumand na ndroch - dhaoine ( agas do thairrngir Pól / naomh - [L7v]
tha sin , an uair tug sé a aithne dona Córuinteachaibh an
t - adhultrach coirpthe colach d ’ athchur agas d ’ indarbadh
uathadh , agā rādha mar so : ‘ Cuiridh beagān do thaos tsearbh
nó ghoirt an t - arán uile a seirbhe nó a ngoirte ’ ) ; an treas 2785
adhbhar , do chum go ngēbhadh neach do smachtughadh nó
do chūrsadh náire fāna lochtaibh , agas go dtiucfadh sé mar
sin lé h - aithrighe do chum leighis agas leasaighthe ; agas is
don chūrsadh - sa ghoireas an t - Easbul ‘ toirbheartas do
tSatān , do chum a anma nō a sbioraide do bheith saor a ló 2790
an Tighearna ’ ; is inand sin agas an droch - dhuine do smach -
tughadh lé cūrsadh ar eagla go rachadh a anam i ndamnadh
suthain .

Mās eadh , is in - chomhtharraidh ar tús go bfuil an smach -
tughadh nó an t - ordughadh - sa nó an riaghail - se , uaigneach 2795
nó follas ; uaigneach ar tús , mar atá dā ndēnadh duine locht
chugad do ghnīomharthuibh nó do bhriathruibh , tú dā
chomhairleachadh go brāithreamhail / eadrad féin agas é ; [L8]
agas eisean do dhiūltadh do chomhairle cairdeamhla - sa , nō
fós dá dhearbhadh dhuit lé gnáthughadh a mhí - bhēs nach 2800
bfuil rún ro - leasaighthe aige ; and sin , ’ na dhiaidh sin an
dara h - uair , a theagasg a bfiadhnuise deise nó trír d ’ fhiadh -
nuise maith , agas fós eisean d ’ anmhuin go dúr daingean ina
ainbfios féin agas ina tseachrán , dlighthear and sin , mar
iarras ar Slānuighthōir Crīost , a fhoillseachadh agas a noch - 2805
tadh don Eagluis , iondas , do réir an smachtaighe fhollais ,
go dtucthar do chum na h - eagluise lé h - aithrighe é , nó go
ndēntar dīoghaltus do réir a locht air .

Agas atáid and so trí neithe is in - chomhtharraigh a
dtimcheall an smachtaighe uaignigh . An céd - ní dhīobh , ar 2810
gcomhairle agas ar dteagasg do theacht ó tslighidh agas ó
thoil mhaith agas ó dheagh - choinsias , ag iarraidh chosanta
ar mbrāthar nī sa mó iná do iarrfamaois sgandail do thabh -
airt dó . An dara ní , a dheirbh - fhios do bheith againd go
dtuillid a lochta / achmhasān do réir bhriathar nDé . Agas [L8v]
fá dheōidh , sind do ghnāthughadh na méide - sin do ghliocas
agas do tsēimhidheacht , iondas dā rabh méid ēigin d ’ amharas
againd san adhbhar ina mbiam agā theagasg , go ma h - ēidir
lind maille ré briathruibh diadha a tharraing do thuigsin a
locht féin ; nó dā mbeanaidh an locht ré mórān , nō a bheith 2820
follas do mhóran , ar dteagasg - ne do bheith a bfiadhnuise
choda éigin dīobh .

A dtimcheall smachtaighe fhollais na h - Eagluise , atá so
síos ion - choimhéda , mar atá gan aoin - neach dá ndēnadh coir 2830
nó cionta d ’ fhāgbhāil gan chiontughadh lé gné éigin chion - /
taighe . Uair ar bith dá mothōchuighe seachrán sa choimh - [M
thionōl do dhroch - eisimlāir nó do sgandail mhí - bhés nó
neamh - chosamhlachta rēna n - admhāil Crīosdaidhe , mar atá
dā rabh duine santach , nó adhaltrach , nó siūrtuidhe , nó fear 2835
éthigh , nó gadaidhe , nó fear ghabhāla ceandaigh a n - adhaidh
na córa , nó fear fiadhnuise brēige do dhēnamh , nó fear
sgandaile , nó fear meisge , nó fear labhartha blaisbhéime ,
nó úsuruidhe , nó én - phearsa easumhal bhuaidheartha , nó
lucht eiritice nó saobh - chreidimh nó droch - tsligheadh , mar 2840
atáid Pápānaigh , Anabaptistidh , agas a gcosamhlacht oile :
agas fós go h - aithghearr , gach uile ní do - dhēnadh salchur
nó cáidhe d ’ fhāgbhāil ar an Eagluis Chrīosduidhe , agas gach
ní nach gcuidigheand ris an Eagluis chēdna , ní dhligheand
sé dul as gan teagasg nó gan dīoghaltas . 2845

Agas ar son gurab minic theagbhus don Eagluis Chrīosd -
aidhe gurab éigean dōibh , an tan nach bfoghnand leigheas /
oile and , an t - slat - sa na n - easbul ris a rāitear ceartughadh [M1v]
nó cūrsadh do ghabhāil chuca ( óir así sin slat is mó agas is
truime bheanas ris an minisdreacht sbioratalta ) , uime sin 2850
atá arna ordughadh gan én - ní do dhēnamh fān adhbhur - sin
acht maille ré comhairle agas ré toil na h - Eagluise go h -
uilidhe , agas fós dlighid oirchill mhaith agas aire do thabh -
airt nach ullmha do bheidīs do chum dhaoine do chur ōn
gcoimhthionōl nó dhā ngabhāil a rís a gcomh - aonta agas 2855
a gcumand na h - Eagluise , mar atáid na daoine ina mothōch -
adaois ullmhacht aithrighe ; agas fós gan a gcur ó ēisteacht
na searmōna ( gé dho bheiddīs a bfēgmhuis chuidighe na
Sacramuinteadh agas ghnāthuighe oile na h - Eagluise ) , do
thabhairt tsaoirse agas tsligheadh do chum aithrighe dhōibh . 2860
Agas fá dheōidh , gach smachtughadh , gach ceartughadh ,
gach teagasg , gach achmhasan , gach dīoghaltas , agas gach
cūrsadh dā ndēntar san Eagluis , gan a ndul ní is faide , nó /
gan a bheith ní is truime , inā mar iarras focal Dé go ladh - [M2
amhail , maille ré trōcaire , a ndēnamh agas a ngnāthughadh . 2865

A DHE UILE - CHUMHACHTAIGH agas a [M2v]
Athair is mó trōcaire , ní h - é adhbhur ar dtais - 2875
bēnta and so a bfiadhnuise do chumhachtadh diadha - san
do dhēnamh dhóchais as ar ngnīomharrthaibh féin nó as ar
dtuillteanas , acht as do thrócaire imarcoidh - se , mar do
gheall tú ar nguidhe d ’ ésteacht agas ar n - iarratuis do thabh -
airt dúinn do - nīmaoid ort a n - ainm do Mhic inmhuin Iosa 2880
Crīosd ar dTighearna , neoch tug aithne dhúinn sind féin do

chruindiughadh agas do thinōl a gceand a chéile ina ainm -
sean , lé lán - ghealladh dearbhtha go mbia sé féin ’ nar measg
agas ’ nar meadhon ; agas ní h - é sin amhāin , acht go mbia sé
againd mar aidhne agas mar theachtaire do thaoibh do 2885
chumhachta - sa , d ’ fhaghāil dúinn gach uile neithe dá bfaicfe
do thoil bheandaidhthe - se in - tugtha dār riachtanas a leas .
Uime sin atámaoid ’ gud ghuidhe agas ’ gud ghér - atach , a
Athair is mó trōcaire , do ghnúis ghrádhach d ’ impōdh
chugaind , agas gan ar bpeacaidh iomar / cacha nō ar seach - [M3
rāin shaobha d ’ agra nó do leanmhuin oruind , an ní lēr thuil -
leamar do réir córa agas cothruim t ’ fhearg - sa agas do ghér -
dhíghaltus do theacht oruind ; acht gabh sind ad thrócaire
ar son Iosa Crīosd , ag gabhāil a bháis agas a phāise - sean mar
lán - ēraic ar n - uile olc - ne , ar son gurab and - san amhāin atá 2895
do thoil , agas nach édir leat t ’ fhearg do bheith rinde thríd - sin .

Agas ar bfaicsin gur chuireamar an oidhche - se thoraind
a suan agas a suaimhneas , deōnaidh dúinn , a Athair neamh -
dha , an lā aniudh agas gach én - lá eile feadh ar mbeathadh
do chaitheamh go h - uilidhe ad sheirbhīs - se , iondas go dtí 2900
dār n - uile smuaintighibh , dār n - uile bhriathraibh , agas dār
n - uile oibridhibh , glóir th ’ anma naomhtha - sa d ’ adhmoladh ,
agas deagh - esimlāir do thabhairt dá gach én - duine , iondas
an tan do - chífid ar ndeagh - oibridhe go dtiubhraid glōir
duit - se , ar n - Athair neamhdha . Agas fós an mhéid nár lōr 2905
leat , dod thrócaire shaoir féin agas / dod ghrádh , ar gcruth - [M3v]
ughadh do réir th ’ fhioghrach féin agas do chosmhuluis
amhāin , acht maille ris sin do thogh tú sind mar oidhreadh -
aibh maille rēd Mhac mór - ghrádhach Iosa Crīosd ar an
Rīgheacht ro - bhuain - sin do ullmhuigh tú féin dúinn roimh 2910
thosach an t - saoghail , atāmaoid ’ gud ghuidhe ar gcreideamh
agas ar dtuigse do mhédughadh , agas ar gcroidheadha
d ’ fhoillsiudhadh lēd Sbiorad Naomhtha , as go bfédam anois
ar n - aimsear do chaitheamh a n - ámhaillibh diadha agas a
nglan - ghnīomharthaibh beathadh . Oir atá a fhios againd 2915
nach bfaghaid daoine íodholacha , nó daoine adhaltracha , nó
daoine santacha , nó daoine conassacha , nó daoine mesgeacha ,
nó lucht craois , nó a gcosmhulus eile sin , oidhreacht Rīogh -
achta Dé .

Agas ar son go dtug tú a aithne dhúinn , gach aon dínn 2920
do dhēnamh guidhe d ’ aroile , ní h - ar ar son féin amhāin , a
Thighearna , agas ar son na méide do ghoir tú roimhe so go
dtuigse fhīrindigh do thoile neamhdha atāmaoid ag dēnamh
ar / nguidhe , acht ar son gach uile phobuil agas chinēl sa [M4
saoghal , neoch mur thuigid as t ’ oibrighibh ingantacha gurab 2925
tú féin Dia ós na h - uilibh , gurab amhluidh sin is toil leat a
dteagusg lēd Sbiorad Naomh , agas a n - uile dhóchas do
dhēnamh indad - sa , a n - aon - Slānuighthōir agas a bfear -
saortha . Acht ō nach ēdir leó sin do chreideamh gan a
chloisdin , agas nach ēdir a chloisdin acht lé searmōin , agas 2930
nach ēdir lē h - ēn - duine searmōin do dhēnamh acht muna
cuirthear do chum searmōine iad ; uime sin , a Thighearna ,
brosnuigh agas tógaibh suas a n - airde randadōruighe fīrin -
deacha fīr - dhiadha ar do dhiamhraibh féin , neoch chuirfeas
ar gcūl gach uile tharraing tsaoghalta agas iarras do ghlōir - 2935
se amhāin ina dteagusg agas ina ndeagh - bheathaidh . Agas
go contrárrdha dhó sin , claoi Satān agas an Anticrīosd
maille rēna n - uile lucht - tuarastail , agas lēna bPāpānachaibh ,
atá agad thrēigean - sa agas arna dtoirbhirt a gcédfadha / ibh [M4v]
damanta . Impōidh a gcroidheadha nó coisg a gcumhachta , 2940
iondas nach édir leó lēna slighthibh nō lēna siosmaibh nō
lēna n - ain - chreideamh nō lēna seachrānaibh , buaidhreadh
do dhēnamh ar do bheg - thréd - sa .

Agas ar bfaicsin , a Thighearna , go dtāngamuir - ne isna
laithibh dēighionacha - sa agas san aimsir chuntabhartaigh - se , 2945
inar ghabh ainbfios foirrneart , agas ina bfuil Satān gona
mhuintir ag iarraidh gach uile tsligheadh do mhūchadh
tsoillse do tSoiscēl - se , atāmaoid ’ gud ghuidhe agas ’ gud ghér -
atach tú do chothughadh agas do sheasamh th ’ adhbhuir
féin a n - adhaigh na mac - dtíre dtrēn - urchōideach - sa , agas 2950
tabhair neart agas comhfhurtacht dod tsearbhōntuibh féin
atá a ndaoirse agas a bprīsūnaibh . Nā tugadh t ’ fhad -
fhoighide adhbhur dhōibh do mhēdughadh a dtīrēnacht agas
a bfoirrnearta fīor - aingidhe , nó fós do chur mheatachta ar
do mhaoth - chloind - se ; agas fós nā bacadh ar bpeacaidh - ne 2955
nó ar n - aingidheacht do thrō / caire - se acht , a Thighearna , [M5]

2920 : aón .
2926 : Diá .
2928 : anaón .
2932 : íad .
2948 : thoillse .
2956 : thro / caircese , but catchword correct .

tabhair aire go luathghāireach ar amhgharaibh agas ar
ghuasachtaibh th ’ Eaglaise ēdtreōraighe féin , atá a n - in -
adhaibh imdha ag fulang dhochair dho - āirmhe ó chuthach
chruaigh - chalma a námhad . Agas adbhamaoid , a Thigh - 2960
earna , gurab oircheas tigid na dochair - se oraind ar son ar
bpeacadh ; óir gidh imdha do thioghluicthe agas do thoir -
bhertuis dúinn , lé dtairrngeand tú sind do thabhairt ghráidh
dhuit , agas gé minic do bhagar dīoghaltuis oraind , rēr chóir
dhúinn th ’ eagla do bheith oraind agas aithridhe ēscaidh 2965
ullamh do dhēnamh , gidh eadh atāmaoid do ghnáth ag
anmhuin ’ nar n - aingidheacht agas ’ nar n - olc féin , agas nī
fhuilid ar gcroidheadha ag tuigsin trom - urchōide ar bpeacadh
mar budh cóir dhóibh a dtuigsin . Uime sin , a Thighearna ,
cruthaidh - se croidhedha nuaidhe indaind , iondas go madh 2970
éidir lind lé intindibh dūthrachtacha ar bpeacaidh féin do
chaoineadh , lé tuirse agas lé dobrōn agas lé dibeargōid ,
agas / aithridhe agas aithrechas dā ríribh do dhēnamh ar [M5v]
son ar n - aingidheachta agas ar n - ámhailleadh neamh - dhiadha
at adhaigh - se . Agas gé nach aithnidh dúinn do phardūn - sa 2975
nō do mhaitheamhnas d ’ fhaghāil dínn féin nō dār ngnīomh -
arrthaibh , gedh eadh atāmaoid go h - umhal ómanta ’ gud
ghuidhe - se agas ’ gud ghér - atach , ar son Iosa Crīosd , do
thrōcaire d ’ fhoillsiughadh oraind , agas ar ngabhāil a rís at
fhabhor agas at fhīor - ghrásaibh . Deōnaidh , a Athair 2980
ghrádhaigh , na h - iarratuis - se dúinn , agas na h - uile ní ar a
bfuil ar bfeidhm agas feidhm th ’ Eagluise - se féin go h - uilidhe ,
do réir do gheallaidh dhúinn a n - Iosa Crīosd ar dTighearna ,
óir is ’ na ainm - sean do - nímaoid t ’ eadar - ghuidhe , mar do
theagaisg sé féin dúinn , ag rádha , Ar n - Athair - ne atá ar 2985
neamh , &c .

O A THIGHEARNA agas a Dhé agas a Athair
bhioth - bhuain , atá lán / do thrócaire , atāmaoid [M6]
agā thuigsin agas agá admhāil nach fiú sind féin ar súile do 2990
thōgbhāil d ’ amharc suas do chum neimhe , agas gurab ludha
iná sin is fiú sind ar dtaisbēnadh a bfiadhnuise do chumhach -
tadh diadha - sa lé dóchas go n - ēisdfeá - sa ar n - iarratus nó ar

n - urrnuidhe , dá dtugam ar n - aire don ní do thuilleamar féin .
Oir atáid ar gcoinsiasa agar n - agra agas atáid ar bpeacaidh 2995
ag dēnamh fhiadhnuise ’ nar n - adhaidh , agas atá a fhios
againd fós gurab breitheamh cothrum ceirt - bhreathach
thusa , nach moland na daoine peacthacha aingidhe , acht
smachtuidheas lochta uile lucht luath - bhrisde th ’ aitheantadh
Gidh eadh , a Athair is truime trócaire , ó do dheōnuidhis a 3000
aithne do thabhairt dúinn sind dot eadar - ghuidhe inar
n - uile thrioblōidibh agas inar n - uile amhgharaibh , ag geal -
ladh cungnamh agas cuideachadh do dhēnamh lind san uair -
sin féin a mothuidhemaoid sind féin mar do bheithmaois ar
ar slugadh don bhás agas do neamh - dhóchas , / atāmaoid [M6v]
go h - uilidhe ag trēigean ar ndóchais tsaoghalta agas ag rith
agas ag ro - tsiubhal do chum do thrócaire trom - ghrádhuighe -
se , mar aon - chādhas agas mar aon - tearmand dúinn , agas
atāmaoid ’ gud ghuidhe agas ’ gud ghér - atach gan ar n - uilc
nó ar n - aingidheacht imarcach do chuimhniughadh dhúinn , 3010
lé bfuilmaoid do ghnáth ag brosnudhadh t ’ fheirge - se agas
do dhiumdha ’ nar n - adhaidh féin . Agas nā cuimhnidh fós
ar ndearmuid nó ar ndīomhaoinis nó ar neamh - chaibhnis
dúinn , ar son nār thuigeamar go diongmhālta , agas nār
nochtamar lēr mbeathaidh ghloin go h - imchubhaidh , comh - 3015
fhurtacht coimh - thrén do tSoisgéil - se atá arna fhoillsiughadh
dhúinn , acht go madh mó ghēbhas tú chugad maille ré
deagh - thoil umhlacht agas bás do Mhic Iosa Crīosd , neoch
do thoirbhir a chorp féin suas mar ofrāil én - uair amháin ’ na
iodhbuirt ar son na n - uile , do dhíol lán - érca ar bpeacaidh - ne 3020
go h - imlān . Dēna trócaire ora / ind uime sin , a Thighearna , [M7]
agas maith ar n - ēgōra dhúinn . Teagaisg sind fós lēd Sbioraid
Naomhtha féin , as go mbreathnōchamaois ar bpeacaidh do
réir mar bhudh cóir , agas go ndēnmaois aithrighe dā ríribh
ar a son ; agas go madh móide , a Thighearna , bhus toil leat 3025
sin d ’ admhāil , a fhaigsin duid nach dēnaid na daoine dam -
anta nó na daoine atá ar diūltadh uaid th ’ adhmoladh nó
th ’ ainm naomhtha d ’ eadar - ghuidhe . Acht asé an croidhe
aithreach , agas así an intind bhrōnach , agas an consias fā
eire an - trom , ar a mbia ocaras agas íota do ghrás - sa , fhoill - 3030

2995 : Oír .
3008 : aón twice .
3012 : chuimhnidh .
3014 : thuigeamhar .
3016 : Tsoisgeilsé .
3017 : gó mádh .
3019 : féín .
3026 : duíd .
3030 : mbiá .
3030 : iotá .

seōchas do ghlóir - se agas do mholadh choidhche . Agas gé
nach bfuilmaoid acht ’ nar bpiasdaibh agas ’ nar n - úir
neamh - ghloin , is tusa ar gCruthuighthōir , agas is sinde
oibridhe do lámh ; is tú fós ar n - Athair , agas is sinde do
chland ; is tú ar n - aodhaire , agas is sinde do thréd ; is tú do 3035
cheandaigh sind , agas is sinde an pobal do cheandaigh tú ;
is tú ar nDia , agas is sinde th ’ oighreacht . / Uime sin nā [M7v]
ceartaigh lét fheirg sind , agas ná déna dīoghaltas do réir ar
mí - ghnīomharthadh oraind , acht smachtaigh go trócaireach
sind lé grádh aithreamhail , iondas go bfaicfe an saoghal go 3040
h - imlān , gidh bé h - uair bhus aithreach leis an pheacthach a
pheacuidh féin ó īochtar agas ó inmheadhōn a chroidhe , go
gcuirfe tusa a mhī - ghnīomhartha as do chuimhne , mar do
gheallais lét fhāidh naomhtha .

Fā dheóidh , mar do bhí do dheagh - thoil - se an oidhche 3045
do chuma don duine do dhēnamh comhnuidhe dhó inte , mar
do chum tú an lá dhó do dhēnamh saothair and , deōnaidh
dhúinne , a Athair ghrádhaidh , suan ciūin corporrdha , iondas
go madh ēidir lēr n - anmandaibh gnáth - fhaire do dhēnamh ,
ag feitheamh ar theacht ar dTighearna Iosa Crīosd dār 3050
saoradh ōn mbeathaidh mbuaidheartha - sa ; agas gan aislinge
nó taibhsidhe , nó sbiorada buaidheartha do bheith a n -
uachtar oraind , acht ar n - intinde go h - uilidhe / do thōgbhāil [M8]
chugad - sa it eagla agas id dhīdean . Tuilleadh eile fós , gan
ar gcodladh do bheith imarcach do réir an - toile ar gcorp 3055
gcomh - thruaillidhe , acht ar gcodladh do bheith foghainteach
do chomhfhurtacht anbfainde ar nádūire , as go madh ull -
mhuide do bheithmaois do chaitheamh ar mbeathadh a
n - āmhaillibh agas a dtrēighibh diadha sin , do mhédughadh
ghlóire th ’ anma naomhtha - sa , agas do chomhfhurtacht ar 3060
gcomharsand agas ar mbrāthar gCrīosduidhe do réir do
thoile diadha - sa . Bīodh amhluidh .

na n - uile chumhacht , agas a Athair neamhdha neamh -
measarrdha , ar son th ’ uile thrócaire agas do chaibhnis
charrthanaigh do nochtais agas do fhoillsidhis / oraind , mar [M8v]
do dheōnaidh do mhaitheas grásamhail lēd thoil thrōcairigh 3070
féin sinde do thogha do chum ar slánuighe roimh thosach an
t - saoghail ; agas a leithēd oile sin do bhuidheachas duit ar
son ar gcruthaidhe do réir cosmhulachta th ’ fhioghrach féin ,
agas ar son ar saortha lé fuil fhīor - naomhtha do Mhic mhōr -
ghrádhaidh féin san am a rabhamur damanta go h - uilidhe , 3075
agas ar son gur bheandaidh tú sind lēd Sbiorad Naomhtha a
bfoillsiughadh agas a dtuigsin do bhriathar mbith - bhuan - sa ,
agas ar son cuidighe agas chumhanta lind ’ nar n - uile fheidhm
agas riachtanas a leas , agas ar son ar bfuasglaidh ó gach uile
chuntabhairt chuirp agas anma , agas ar son ar gcomh - 3080
fhurtachta go cairdeamhail ’ nar n - uile amhgharaibh , agas
ar son ar bfulaing a bfad d ’ aimsir gan dīoghaltus ar bpeacadh
do dhēnamh oraind , acht ag tabhairt aimsire faide ré h -
aithrighe dhúinn . Agas mar thuigmaoid , a Athair is mó
trócaire , na tioghluice - se adubhramar d ’ fhaghāil dú / inn ōd [N
mhaitheas - sa amháin , mar an gcēdna atámaoid ’ gud ghuidhe
a n - ainm do Mhic inmhuin Iosa Crīosd do Sbiorad Naomhtha
féin do dheōnachadh dhúin , as go madh ēdir lind do ghnáth
bheith ag tabhairt bhuidheachais duit - se , ag sīor - leanmhuin
na fīrinde , agas ag faghāil comhfhurtachta uait - se ’ nar n - uile 3090
dhoghruindibh agas dhocamhlaibh . A Thighearna , daing -
nidh ar gcreideamh agas fadōidh é nī sa mó a dteas agas a
ngrádh mar dhlighmaoid duit - se agas dār gcomharsandaibh .
Nā fuluing dúinn , a Athair ghrádhaidh , do bhriathra do dhul
ní as sia dhúinn i ndīomhaoineas , acht deōnaidh dhúinn do 3095
ghnáth comhfhurtacht do ghrás agas do Sbiorad Naomhtha ,
iondas go bfēdmaoid adhragh dot ainm naomhtha - sa lēr
gcroidheadhaibh agas lēr mbriathruibh agas lēr ngnīomh -
arthaibh .

Mēdaidh féin , a Thighearna , agas cuir a leithead do 3100
Rīghacht agas do chumhachta , iondas go bfēdaim - ne bheith
lán nó dīolta dod dheagh - tho / il - se , gidh bé ar bith ní do [N1v]
dheōnuidhis dhúinn . A Athair ghrádhaidh , nā lég oraind
uireasbhuidh na neitheand nach bfēdmaoid theacht ’ na

bfēgmhuis do dhēnamh do tseirbhīse , acht beandaidh - se 3105
sind agas oibridhe ar lámh ré chéile , iondas go mbiadh ar
riachtanas a leas againd gan ar n - eire do bheith ar chách
acht go madh mó bhiam in - chuidighe leó . Dēna trócaire
oraind , a Thighearna , agas ar ar n - uile lochtaibh ; agas ar
bfaicsin gurab mór na fiacha do mhaith tusa dhúinn ar son 3110
Iosa Crīosd , tabhair oraind an mhéid - sin do bharr gráidh do
thabhairt duit - se agas dār gcomharsandaibh . Bí féin againd
ad t ’ athair agas ad cheand - feadhna agas ad t ’ fhear - dídin ;
congaibh agad sind ad láimh thrōcairidh a n - am ar n - uile
bhuaidhearrtha , dār saoradh ó na h - uile urchōidibh , agas 3115
do chrīchnudhadh ar mbeathadh a n - umhlu agas a n -
onōrudh th ’ anma naomhtha - sa , trīd Iosa Crīosd ar dTigh -
earna agas ar n - aon Slānuighthōir . Bīodh amhlu / idh . [N2

Tabhair tuigse dhamh , agas coimhéda mé do ladh ;
coimhédfa mé é lé mo chroidhe / go h - uilidhe . [N2v]

go madh toil leat maille ris sin mo thuigse do tsoillsiughadh , 3140
atá dā nádūir féin dall , iondas go madh édir leam an t - eólus
agas an teagasg mūinfidhear dhamh do ghabhāil chugam lé
deagh - thuigse ; agas go madh toil leat mo chuimhne do
threōrughadh agas do dhaingniughadh do choimhéd m ’ fhodh -
luma , agas fós mo chroidhe do cheartughadh do ghabhāil na 3145
nglan - teagasg sin lé toil thindeasnaidh , mar is imchubhaidh ,
iondas nach rachadh mo tsaothar a ndolaidh oram do bhrīdh
mo dhīmhaoinis nó mo neamh - bhuidheachais ar do thiogh -
luicibh trom - dhiadha - sa ; go madh toil leat fós do Sbiorad
Naomhtha féin do dhortadh ora / ind dá choimhlīnadh so [N3
. i . Sbiorad na tuigse , agas na fīrinde , agas an bhreith -
eamhnuis , agas an ghliocais , agas an ghlain - eōluis , lé bfétar
misi do dhēnamh aibél do ghabháil thoraidh an t - saothair
agas an dochair do - geibhthear rē mo theagasg chugam ,
iondas nach racha sin a ndīomhaoineas damh . Agas a 3155
Thighearna , ge bé h - aigneadh ar a dtiubhra mé aire , tabhair
oram sin do chaitheamh do chum na crīche diadha dlistean -
aidhe . i . tusa do thuigsin inar dTighearna Iosa Crīosd , agas
go madh édir leam lán - ndóchas mo tslānuighe do bheith agam
ad ghrásaibh - se , agas seirbhīs dhíreach dhiongmhālta do 3160
dhēnamh dhuit do réir do thoile féin , iondas ge bé ní do -
nīm d ’ fhoghlaim go madh adhbhur cuidighe agas cumhanta
do chum na seirbhīse - sin damh é .

Agas ar bfaicsin gur gheall tú gliocas dona daoinibh beaga
umhla , agas gur gheall tú claoidh agas comh - thuargaint do 3165
dhēnamh ar na daoinibh dīomhsacha lé comh - mbuaidhre /
adh a gcēdfadh , agas gur gheall tú thú féin do thaisbēnadh [N3v]
do lucht na gceart - chroidheadh , agas fós na daoine aingidhe
neamh - dhiadha do dhalladh ; atāim - se ’ gud ghuidhe agas
’ gud ghér - atach mē féin do chórughadh agas do chaitheamh 3170
a n - umhla fhīrindigh , iondas gurab í tús m ’ fhodhluma mo
bheith umhal orramach ómanta dod chumhachtaibh diadha -
sa , agas ’ na dhiaidh sin dona h - uachtarānaibh agas dona
h - aird - thighearnaibh do ordaigh tusa ōs mo chiond ; agas go
madh toil leat mo chroidhe d ’ ullmhudhadh go neamh - 3175
chealgach dot onōrughadh - sa , agas do thrēigean uile olc

agas an - toile na feōla agas in chuirp ; agas mé dom ull -
mhughadh féin mur sin do dhēnamh do tseirbhīse san inmhe
nó sa sdaid ina dtoil leat - sa mo chur , an tan thiucfas mé do
chum aoise foirfi . Na tiodhluice - se , agas gach tiodhlucadh 3180
maith eile , iarraim ort , a Athair na trōcaire , a n - ainm do
Mhic Iosa Crīosd , mur do theagaisg sé féin damh ag / rādha , [N4
Ar n - Athair - ne atá ar neamh , &c .

A THIGHEARNA AGAS A DHE , agas a Athair
is mó trócaire , agas a tSlānuighthōir , ó do 3190
dheōnaidh tú aithne do thabhairt dúinn obair do dhēnamh
d ’ fhurtacht ar n - uireasbhadha agas ar bfeadhma , atāmaoid
ag eadar - ghuidhe do ghrás ar n - obair do bheandachadh , as
go soitheōchadh an beandachadh - sin chugaind féin , óir ní
cosmhuil gura buan sind ’ na fhēgmhais sin , iondas go 3195
ndēnand toirbheartus do bheandaidhe oraind fiadhnuise
dhúinn ar an gcúrum agas ar an ngrādh aithreamhail atá
agat ós ar / gciond . Tuilleadh eile , a Thighearna , atāmaoid [N4v]
’ gud ghér - ghuidhe ar neartughadh lēd Sbiorad Naomhtha ,
do thabhairt oraind obair fhírindeach gan fhallsacht gan 3200
cheilg do dhēnamh sa sdaid agas san inmhe inar chuir tú
sind ; agas fós go madh mó an dīthcheall do - dhēnam do
leanmhuin th ’ orduighe oirrdheirc - se agas do reachta ro -
naomhtha , nó do leanmhuin līonaidh ar dtoileadh santacha
féin agas ghráidh ēdála . Agas māsa thoil leat - sa a Thigh - 3205
earna , biseach do bhrīdh do bheandaidhe féin do theacht ar
ar n - obair , tabhair intinde dhúinn do chuidiughadh leis na
daoinibh ar a bfuil feidhm cuididhe , do réir na gcumhachta
ina dtoil léd ghrásaibh sin do thabhairt dúinn , agas ar

dtuigsin dúinn gurab uait - se tig gach uile ní maith , deónaidh 3210
dhúinn sind dār n - umhlughadh agas dār n - ísliughadh dār
gcomharsandaibh , agas gan sind dār dtōgbhāil féin i ndī -
omus ós a gciond , gé nach bfuaradar uiread comhranda
neith rinde ód thrócaire - / se . Agas mása thoil leat sinde féin [N5]
d ’ fhéchain agas do cheasnughadh lé barr bochtaine agas 3215
uireasbhadha , ní sa mó nó dob āil lé toil ar gcorp , go madh
toil leat - sa and sin , a Thighearna , gan ar dtreōrughadh do
thuitim a neamh - dhóchas , acht do ghrása do thabhairt
dúinn do thuigsin agas d ’ admhāil go mbeathaidheand agas
go n - altromand tú féin do ghnāth do bhrīdh do thrócaire 3220
saoire sind , agas go mbemaoid go foidhideach ag feitheamh
ort nó go dtabhra tusa sásadh dhúinn , ní h - amháin do
ghrásaibh nó do thioghluicibh corporrdha , acht go speisialta
do tsaibhreas neamhda nua - sbioratālta , do chum sin dār
mbrosnudhadh do thabhairt mholaidh agas mhór - bhuidh - 3225
eachais duit - se , a Thighearna , agas mur sin do ghnáth gan
gluasacht do bheith ad thrócaire - se amháin . Eisd sind , a
Thighearna na trócaire , ar grádh do Mhic inmhuin Iosa
Crīosd ar dTighearna . Amen . /
Urrnuidhe in - rādha gidh bé h - uair bhus āil leat . [N5v]

ar mire agas ar mór - dhe / armad an tan do - gheibh sí saoirse [N6]
agas sonas lé tiodhluicibh corparrdha .

Gidh eadh , a Athair inmhuin , atá do ghliocas - sa fuaithe
rēd thrócaire , iondas go bfēchand tú gach én - tslighe do
thabhairt do chloinde féin do chum aithne agas tuigse do
bhrīdh do ghráidh aithreamhail orra ; agas uime sin , an tan 3250
nach bfoghnand sonas agas socracht dhōibh , is bés duit - se
and sin daibhreas agas dochair do thabhairt dōibh , agas
th ’ uile chland féin do cheartughadh agas do smachtughadh
mar sin , an mhéid do ghabhais chugad ad theaghlach
naomhtha dhīobh . Uime sin atámaoid - ne , na daoine peac - 3255
thacha bioth - bhochta - sa , ag tabhairt bhuidheachais duit - se
lé croidheadhaibh umhla , ar son gur dheōnaigh tú ar ngairm
do chum do theaghaise agas do theaghluidh lé smachtughadh
aithreamhail ar son an dīmheasa do - rindeamar ar na grásaibh
do fhurāil tú oraind a n - am ar socrachta agas ar sólāis . Oir 3260
dob ēidir leat - sa lé / ceirt - bhreitheamhnus sind do thoir - [N6v]
bheart agas do thiodhlucadh dār n - intindibh dúra damanta
féin agas dār gcroidheadhaibh cruaidhe cealgacha cloch , a
n - éraic an dīmhesa - sin adubhramar , agas a n - éraic imad ar
bpeacadh fuathmhur fíor - ghrānda oile , atámaoid d ’ agra 3265
oraind féin and so at fhiadhnuise - se , mar do - rinde tú ar
mhórán oile romhaind . Acht cheana , a Thighearna , atá an
mhéid - sin do mhaitheas iondad - sa go bfaicear dhúinne gur
dhearmuid tú ar n - uile pheacaidh , agas gur ghoir tú sind ōn
uile īodhulacht agas urchōid ina rabhamar báite do chum 3270
ard - admhāla th ’ anma - sa , agas d ’ iumchur chroiche éigne ar
son fhīrinde do tSoisgēil - se a measg do phoibleach , ag dēnamh
fhiadhnuise lét fhāidhibh - se agas lét easbulaibh , agas nī sa
mó léd Mhac ionmhuin Iosa , ar gCeand agas ar gCodhnach ,
neoch rér thindsgain tú sinde do dhēnamh cosmhuil , do 3275
chum ar mbeith cosmhuil ris an tan fhoillsidheas sé é féin
ina ghlōir . A Thighe / arna agas a Dhé , créd sinde féin , ar a [N7]
bfuil tusa ag foillsiughadh na ngrás - sa ? A Thighearna
thairise , maith dhúinn ar neamh - mbuidheachas agas ar
n - uile pheacaidh ar grádh Iosa Crīosd . A Athair ghrádhaidh , 3280
médaigh do Sbiorad Naomhtha féin iondaind fós do theagasg
ar gcroidheadh do ghairm Abba , Athair inmhuin , agas do

dhaingniughadh dhúinn ar dtogha tsīoruighthe a gCrīosd ,
agas d ’ fhoillsiughadh a thoile dhúinn nī sa lia agas nī sa lia ,
agas dār gceangal at fhīrinde - se , iondas go bfédam ar mbeatha 3285
do chaitheamh agas bás d ’ fhulang sa bfīrinde - sin ; agas go
madh éidir lind do bhrīdh oibrighe an Sbioraid adubhramar
cúntus do thabhairt ’ nar gcreideamh dā gach nduine iarrfas
oraind é , lé caibhneas agas lé ceart agas lé cóir , mar atāid
mórān ag ar n - ithimrādh agas ag tabhairt sgandaile dhúinn , 3290
mar do bheithmaois ’ nar lucht uilc imarcaidh , go ma h -
amhlaidh sin anois , ar bfaicsin ar ndeagh - bheathai - ne a
gCrīosd , bhus éidir leó / náire dá ngabhāil fān sgandail do - [N7v]
bheirid go neimh - chiontach dhúinne , agas a mbeōil do
dhrud ó adhbhar na sgandaile - sin . Atāmaoid fós ’ gud ghér - 3295
atach , a Thighearna , an coimhthionōl - sa do bheandachadh
agas do riaghladh , do mholadh th ’ anma naomhtha féin .
Atāmuid fós ’ gud ghuidhe , thú féin do bheith ’ nar bfochair
agas a measg do chloinde do - ní tinōl at ainm diadha féin ,
agas atāmuid ’ gud ghuidhe bheith a bfochair agas a bfarradh 3300
ar n - uile bhrāthar gCriosduidhe ar feadh an domhain go
h - imlán , iondas go madh éidir leó agas linde , do bhrīdh
bhrosnuidhe Sbioraid na fīrinde , gan féchain do chuntabh -
airt tsaoghalta , fá bheith ag iarraidh th ’ onōra - sa amháin
agas do ghlōire , agas ag admholadh th ’ anma naomhtha atá 3305
beanduighthe a saoghal na saoghal . Bīodh amhluidh . /

3284 : second liá .
3287 : oibríghe .
3291 : gomá .

MODH CEASNUIGHE NA N - OGANACH [N8]
sol chaithid Suipēr an Tighearna , agas
FOIRCEADUL AITHGHEARR
an Chreidimh Chrīostaidhe , 3310
and so síos .

D . Ní fhuilid gan amharus acht ina n - a / on - Dia , gé táid [N8v]
edir - dhealaidhthe a dtrí pearsandaibh .

M . Ciondas ele thuigeas tú na bria / thra do labhair Crīosd [O
rēna Easpuluibh , an tan do iarr sé orra an Soisgél d ’ fhoill -
siudhadh dona h - uile chrēatūiribh , agas an Sbiorad Naomh
do ghabhāil chuca , agas gē bé dā maithfidīs a bpeacaidh , go 3340
maithfeadh sesean a bpeacaidh dōibh sin , agas gē bé dá nach
maithfidīs a bpeacaidh , nach maithfeadh sesean a bpeacaidh
dōibh ?

M . Créd eile cuid an t - Sagairt nō an Mhinistir do mhaith -
eamh na bpea / cadh , an tan gheallas sé maitheamh a bpea - [O1v]
cadh dona daoinibh do - ní aithrighe ?

D . Gurab é Dia Athair Iosa Crīosd ar dTighearna agas 3365
ar n - Athair - ne uile is tossach agas is adhbhur prindsipālta
dá gach uile ní , agas go bfuil sé agā riaghladh , as nach dēntar
én - ní gan a ordughadh agas a fhreasdal . / ’ Na dhiaidh sin , [O2
go dtāinic a Mhac Iosa Crīosd anuas sa saoghal , agas gur
choimhlīon sé gach uile ní in - fheadhma dar slánughadh - ne , 3370
agas go ndeachaidh sé suas ar neamh , mur a bfuil sé ar deas -
lāimh an Athar , agas gurab aige atá gach uile chumhachta
ar neamh agas ar talmhuin , agas go dtiucfa sé a rís as sin do
dhēnamh bhreitheamhnais ar an t - saoghal go h - uilidhe .
Tuilleadh eile fós , gurab Dia fīrindeach an Sbiorad Naomh , 3375
ar son gurab é brígh agas neart agas cumhachta Dé é , agas
gurab é chuireas a gcló ’ nar gcroidheadhaibh na geallaidh do -
rindeadh dhúinn a n - Iosa Crīosd . Agas fā dheóigh , go bfuil
an Eagluis arna naomhadh agas arna saoradh ōna peacaibh
tríd thrócaire Dhé , agas go n - éreōchaidh sí tar éis na beath - 3380
adh - sa do chum na beathadh suthaine .

M . An é gurab lór dhúinn sin do thuigsin agas do chreid -
eamh gan én - ndeagh - ghnīomh do dhēnamh ō sin / amach ? [O2v]

D . Adeirim go fírindeach nach bfuil d ’ fhiachaibh oruind [O3
én - ghnáthughadh atá a n - adhaidh bhriathar nDé do lean -
mhuin , agas fós gur chumadar na sagairt mōrān do ghnāth -
ughadh seirbhīse dhūinn , do - nímaois do Dhia , dar leó - san ,
agas gurab easonōir do Dhia a lán dibh .

M . Créd eile an t - slighe dob áil leat - sa do ghabhāil
chugad do thabhairt onōra do Dhia acht an t - slighe do
ghnáthuigheadar do tsindsir romhad , agas do theagaisg an 3415
Pápa agas / an Eagluis ré fada dh ’ aimsir ? [O3v]

Is mise an Tighearna do Dhia , neoch tug thussa a talamh 3430
na h - Egbhite agas a teaghais na daoirse . Nā bíodh Dēe oile
agad am fhiadhnaise - se . Nā dēna dhuit féin íomhāigh /
ghrafinte , nō én - fhighuir na neithe atá tsuas ar neamh , nō [O4
a dtalmhuin a bhos , nō a n - uisceadhaibh faoi thalmhuin .
Ná gēill - se dhōibh , agas nā dēna seirbhis dóibh , óir is mise 3435
an Tighearna do Dhia , agas is Dia ēdmhar mé , leanas
aingidheacht na n - aithreach ar an gcloind go nuige an treas
nō an ceathramhadh cém nō glún gheinealaidh ar an droing
agā mbia m ’ fhuath , agas fhoillseōchas trócaire dona míltibh
don droing agā mbia mo ghrádh , agas choimhēdas mh ’ aith - 3440
eanta . Nā tabhair ainm an Tighearna do Dhia féin a
ndímhaoineas , óir gé bé bhéras a ainm go dímhaoineach , ní
budh neamh - chiontach a bfiadhnuise Dé é .

Cuimhnidh lá na Sabbōide do chongbhāil a saoire . Dēna
th ’ oibrighe a sé laithibh , agas th ’ uile tsaothar , acht asé an 3445
seachtmhadh lá Sabbōid nō Sathurn an Tighearna do Dhia .
Nā dēna én - obuir sa ló - sin , nā dēna féin , agas nā dénadh do
mhac , agas nā dénadh th ’ inghean , nō th ’ óglach nō do
bhan - óg / lāch , nō th ’ ainmhidhe , nō an taisteallach bhias [O4v]
taoibh astoigh dod t ’ árus . Oir do - rinde an Tighearna neamh 3450
agas talamh a sé laithibh , agas do - rinde sé an fhairrge fós ,

NOTES

1 Foirm na n - urrnuidheadh :
M ’ L translates “ forms of prayer ” , but foirm is singular and corresponds to the English title ‘ The Form of Prayers ’ . In urrnuidhe spellings with - dh - predominate , though - gh - is found occasionally ; the alternation is widespread in this text ( e . g . ina ndiaigh 38 , a n - adhaidh 54 , ragha 59 , ladh 64 , laodh 78 , loidhed 155 , an - arrsaigh 176 ) as the two had been identical in sound since the thirteenth century ; cf . ID 65 . For the - rr - compare oirrdheirc 34 , tarrla 89 , foirrneart 131 , oirrdhearcas 137 , tighearrntuis 147 , fairrge 170 , an - arrsaigh 176 , and many other examples . Cf . E . Knott ’ s edition of Tadhg Dall O Huiginn , xcvii , which describes “ r medial usually doubled before ch , dh , gh , l , n , s , th , when the preceding vowel is historically short ” as the standard of good seventeenth - century manuscripts .

10 arna dtarraing as Laidin :
for the sense “ translate ” see CDIL svv . tarraing 84 . 70 , do - srenga 377 . 71 . On the language and history of the text that Carswell was translating see the Introduction .

16 do tsuidhiughadh :
for Carswell ’ s use of ts for lenited s see the Introduction .

deals with the history and contents as well as enumerating the editions . Lekprevik was the Kirk ’ s approved printer and we find the General Assembly ( BUK 164 ) assigning him yearly £50 “ having respect to his povertie , the great expenses he hes made in buying of printing yrnes , and the great zeale and love he beares to serve the Kirk at all tymes . ”

23 Giolla Easbuig :
Archibald , the fifth earl , born c . 1530 , died 1575 , further identified as Donn . Cf . Highland Papers , vol . II 101 , and cf . ibid . 72 for “ ane accompt of the Genealogie of the Campbells who were of old called Clann oduibn ( or rather oduibhn ) … from the famous Knights and champions the oduibhns , and especially from Diarmad ( or Jeremie ) oduibhnes famous in the Irish genealogies ; from whom they are sometymes designated Siol - Diarmid or Sliochd Diarmad , … but assumed the surname of Campbells in the days of Malcolm the third … who nevertheless do in their own language keep the names both of Campbells and oduibhns to this day . ” Hence Ua nDuibhne 24 , 402 .

24 Iarrla :
earl at this time , marquess from 1641 ; the ducal title dates from 1701 .
25 Ard - ghiúisdis “ Justiciary ” and Aird - cheand teaghluigh “ Master of the Household ” were titles also held by his father Archibald the fourth earl , who died in 1558 .

26 Lieutenanda :
printed Liue - ; - eu - may have been accidentally transposed but - ue - , i . e . - ve - , is also possible . Something of the kind lies behind our present pronunciation of lieutenant , and f or v spellings were current in both Scotland and England in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries . Cf . Bruce ( ms . of 1489 ) XIV 140 luftenand , and NED s . v . 1c , quotations of 1596 , leauetennant ( Scots ) , Lievetenant ( English ) . With this preservation of v instead of substituting bh , cf . reuerens ,
- ach , in CC . The appointment of the earls of Argyll

29 ag guidhe :
the consonant of ag is regularly assimilated to a following c - or g - and so is omitted in Carswell ’ s spelling . Its loss before other consonants is not yet recognised by the spelling .

33 ō Dhia Athar :
gen . of apposition ; cf . Des . p . 246 , and below 303 , 1115 , 1146 .

35 ar buil :
“ in force ” , “ practised ” , cf . CC 336 a 3 ; for the nom . bail see TSh 5118 .

36 dul a dtarbha do :
“ profit , benefit ” ; see CDIL s . v . torbae 258 . 7 , and cf . below 693 .

41 airidhe :
also 46 , 55 . See SGS II 13 - 14 . The d ’
represents the preposition do ,
and marks the predicative status of the noun , e . g . 41 “ and who is best as one worthy of it ” , “ who is most worthy of it ” . For predicative do cf . d ’ fhiachaibh 92 , do thidhlocadh 241 , d ’ aon - iodhbairt 482 , dh ’ athair 1516 , 1727 .

41 is mó ar a mbī cumaoin ghrāidh fhir dhēnta an t - saothair :
lit . “ and upon whom is the greatest recompense for the love of the author of the work ” , i . e . those who by virtue of their affection for the author have most deserved this gift of the dedication of his book . Similarly 47 , méd do chomaoine grāidh imarcaidh oram ,
lit . “ the extent of your entitlement of abundant love toward me ” , i . e . “ the extent of the obligation I owe you for your great love toward me . ”

44 agā thuigsin :
“ understanding it ” , where the pronoun anticipates the various objects to follow . In such cases it is always masculine singular , even when , as here , the first object is feminine and the objects in the aggregate are plural . Cf . agā rāgha 58 , agā fhoillsiughadh 580 , agā admhāil agas ’ gā thuigsin 830 , agā dhearbhadh 868 , 898 , and similar cases like a aithne do thabhairt dúinn gach aon againd do dhēnamh guidhe 1583 , 2920 .

46 th ’ fheabhus :
before an initial vowel or lenited f - the possessive of the 2nd . pers . sg . regularly has the form h - in Carswell for the etymological th ’ ( which occurs before vowels at 1523 , 3037 , 3068 , and is restored in this edition ) . The f - , as is also usual after the preposition d ’ , is not marked as lenited .

48 do condcus damh - sa :
impersonal preterite “ has been seen ” in the sense of “ has seemed ( good ) to me ” . The sense “ was seen ” is
found at 1945 . Similarly do - cīthear “ seems good ” 1125 , cf . 1296 . At 2886 the active is used to render “ seem ” .

48 gurbh in - dēnta damh … do thoirbheart :
“ that I must present ” . The use of the in - prefix to form a new verbal of necessity is not nearly so common here as in CC , and some cases of the older type without the prefix are also found , as tuicthe 218 , gabhtha 228 , creite 502 , beite 1746 . On the use of dēnamh as an auxiliary see the Introduction .

55 do dhul ar neifnī :
“ perish ” , lit . “ go into nothing ” ; neif -
is a rarer form of the negative prefix neamh - , neimh - ,
as in Old Irish nephní gl . nihil ( GOI § 874 ) .

58 gē tāid :
the pretonic a - of atá , atáid , atámaoid ,
disappears after gé “ though ” , ó “ since ” , and and má “ if ” .

62 inā :
“ than ” ; this is Carswell ’ s regular form , for which see CDIL s . v . indaas . He also has two examples of nō 669 , 1419 ; see CDIL s . v . 7 nó , “ occasionally used in late texts ” .

63 neoch :
relative pronoun , not as a defining but as a descriptive relative , adding further information ; cf . 1744 .

68 an toil - sin Dé :
“ that will of God ” ; when the noun upon which a noun in the gen . depends is qualified by a demonstrative the article is used , although there would be no article in toil Dé “ the will of God ” . Cf . an bás - sin ar Slānaidhthōir 487 , cló na h - īmhāidhe - sin Iosa Crīosd 1992 , na briathra - sa Pōil 2146 , na h - easslāinte - sin agas na teachtairidhe an bháis 2541 ( where the demonstrative is to be understood as applying to teachtairidhe also ) , an t - slat - sa na n - easbul 2848 .

71 sgrībhtha :
predicative , “ in written form ” .

81 Dē na n - uile chumhacht :
“ of God almighty ” , a more idiomatic equivalent of the adjective uile - chumhachtach ,
which nevertheless occurs fairly frequently , e . g . 1115 , 1146 , 1169 , 1174 .

86 Isafat :
Jehoshaphat ; Esecias ,
Hezekiah ; Iosias ,
Josiah . Carswell uses the forms from the LXX and Vulgate transliterations of the Hebrew names , and accordingly Isafat is probably a misprint for Iosafat .
The printer seems to have had some difficulty with Esecias ,
which appears as Esasias here , and Esisias at 140 . This paragraph recalls the argument set forth in the confession of faith adopted on 17 August 1560 ( APS II 534 ) , in the section “ Of the civile Magistrat ” . “ Mairouer to Kingis Princes rewlaris and magistratis we affirme that cheiflie and maist principallie the conversatioun and
purgatioun of the Religioun appertenis … as in David , Josaphat , Ezechias , Josias , and vtheris heichly commendit for thair zeall in that caiss may be espyit . ”

88 an Sbirad Naoimh :
gen . sg . ; for the declension of the noun in Carswell ’ s usage see the Introduction . The adjective generally remains unchanged but occasionally inflects as here and at 461 .

89 Asē adhbhar fā dtarrla dhāibh bheith :
“ this is why they were ” , lit . “ this is the reason on account of which it befell them to be . ” Asē is is é ,
with as ( originally the relative form ) for is ;
cf . Bergin ’ s Stories from Keating ’ s History of Ireland , iv . Tarrla is a subjectless verb occurring only in the past tense , for which see CDIL s . v . do - cuirethar 233 . 39 , 235 . 28 , 236 . 75 , and especially 237 . 73 . Independently in 207 ; “ become ” in 1842 . The verbal noun beith is regularly lenited , even without preceding do ,
and the example to the contrary at 63 should probably be corrected ; cf . Des . p . 270 .

91 nō go raibhe sē d ’ fhiachaibh orra :
“ or that it was as a debt upon them ” , i . e . “ that they were under an obligation to do so . ” Nō go is frequently “ until ” as at 1143 , but here the elements are to be construed separately .

95 an phobaill gheindtlidhe :
cf . 115 . The plural would seem more appropriate , and indeed Carswell often uses it even when referring to a single group , as ag buaidhreadh na bpoibleach 213 , and cf . 345 , 666 , 689 , 805 .

97 do dhlighfedīs :
conditional with pluperfect sense , “ which they ought to have given . ”

115 ag an phoball … go bfuillid :
the - ll in pobal is paralleled at 95 , 1186 , but that in go bfuillid is not , and is probably a misprint .

119 daona :
similarly 1562 ; better daonda 204 , daonna 991 . Cf . CDIL s . v . doénda .

120 gach uile nī rigmaoid a leas :
“ everything we need ” ; for the idiom cf . CDIL s . v . ro - icc 91 . 70 . The a is the possessive “ its ” , but at 1419 and 2516 Carswell has do leas as if he took a as a weakened form of do , as he sometimes has a for do with a verbal noun , as at 98 , 153 , 214 , 708 .

127 dā gach neach :
“ to everyone ” ; before gach the preposition regularly has the form dā not do ,
as at 604 , 803 , 1463 . Cf . CDIL s . v . 1 do 171 . 21 .

148 ar comhairle tSatāin , . i . an ainsbiraid , nāmha … :
“ by the

149 dhā mhēd :
“ however great ” ; for the construction and following dá ,
see Des . p . 253 , and for further examples 320 , and dā fhad 3500 .

151 cuntabhairt :
in the later sense of “ danger ” , as at 183 ( paired with gábhadh and guasacht ) , not in the older sense of “ doubt ” as at 202 , 640 . Modern forms are Sc . G . cunnart ,
Irish contúirt .

153 agas ard - mhonadh … ar gach taobh dībh , agas Faró … ’ na ndiaidh :
the verbless “ and ” clauses , primarily descriptive , are here virtually concessive , “ although there was . ” Cf . CDIL s . v . 2 ocus ( d ) .

160 gan dul :
“ not going ” ; here consecutive , “ so that he did not go . ”

161 uathmhur :
so here and at 846 , 1542 , but subsequently the form fuathmhur with prosthetic f - is used , e . g . 1899 .

165 a h - ucht an Sbirad Naoimh :
similarly a h - ucht agas a n - ainm a Mhic 3628 ; cf . for the first example CDIL s . v . ucht 53 . 48 ( f ) “ by the influence of ” ( parallel to ar aithne Dhé ) , and 53 . 1 ( b ) “ in the name of ” for the second .

178 as a chrand - tabhaill :
see CDIL s . v . táball .

186 a ndēntaoi … do bhunadh :
Professor Matheson understood this as “ in which false sacrifices were accustomed to be established ” , though there seems to be no other evidence for bunadh as a verbal noun . The phrase esbaid do bunad in CIL , rendered “ loss outright ” , suggests that perhaps do bhunadh should be taken with leagadh agas lān - bhriseadh ,
i . e . “ the utter overthrowing and smash -

ing of altars and places where false sacrifices were performed , ” or , with dēntaoi ,
“ were performed from of old . ”

191 mar atā :
introducing examples or instances , “ such as ” ; there is a general distinction in Carswell between mar atá “ namely ” ( more rarely the pl . mar atáid 2856 ) , and mar tá sé “ as it is ” , e . g . 312 , 362 , but mar tá is occasionally found in this sense , as 604 , 1107 . Cf . CDIL s . v . immar II ( a ) 125 . 79 .

203 go bfuilit - seán :
- it for the usual - id because of the voiceless sound following , cf . CDIL s . v . sin 231 . 48 ; - seán for - séan , with the length - mark misplaced as often ; cf . - séan 552 , 1748 , - sean 379 , 1728 , - soin 1148 , - sion 1179 , - sun 393 , and CDIL s . v . 1 sin 231 . 22 , . 33 .

210 na h - Iūbhail :
“ the Jews ” ; but in a gcrīch na n - Iodhbhal 465 “ in the land of the Jews ” ( like a gcrīochaibh Earra - Gaoidheal 13 “ in Argyll ” ) we have what is probably a different form , as is suggested by lucht cumhdaigh … na n - īodhbhal 618 “ idolaters ” . Cf . CDIL s . vv . Ibal , and ídal senses ( a ) and ( c ) .

220 ar son chothaighe agas fhuatha :
gen . of the verbal noun cothughadh ,
more correctly spelt cothaighthe ;
the usual senses are “ maintain , support ” but CIL adds also “ contend , strive ” , meanings which seem more appropriate to cathughadh ,
which Carswell also uses . The examples at 381 , 1338 , 1380 , 1389 , 2194 all belong to the general notion of fighting , resisting , rebelling Cf . cothughadh maith do dhēnamh a n - adhaidh ar nāmhad 1707 , and fā chathughadh cruaidh do dhēnamh a n - adhaidh na nāmhad - sin 1718 . But at 2949 do chothughadh agas do sheasamh th ’ adhbhuir is ‘ to maintain thy cause ’ .

229 mh ’ uireasbhadha : mo loses its vowel before a word beginning in a vowel and is lenited , cf . 272 . Similarly with do ,
on which see note 46 . Cf . Des . p . 360 , and CDIL s . vv . mo 151 . 84 , and 2 do 176 . 70 .

230 oram :
Carswell has only the disyllabic form while Keating and Des . have both ; cf . DIL s . v . for 294 . 44 .

230 a gcanamhain Ghaoidheilge :
the phrase means simply “ in

Gaelic ” , as does a gcanamhain Ghaoidhilge 353 , and as ar gcanamhna Gaoidheilge 307 means “ our Gaelic ” , and as ceart canamhna na Gaoidheilge 366 is equivalent to “ correct Gaelic ” . The Metrical Psalms , both 1659 and 1694 , have a Neaglaisaibh agus a Dteaghlachaibh a ghnathuigheas an chanamhain sin “ in congregations and households that use that language ” , but note that later in his catechism Carswell uses cánoin , canóin .

232 don tí is eōlcha iná mé :
“ to the one who is better informed than I ” . In tí represents the article in t -
with the demonstrative í ,
later analysed as containing a noun tí “ person ” , or as a pronoun “ the one ” ; under the influence of the pronoun sé , é ,
a secondary form té developed as at 673 , 1011 , which in Irish refers , like an tí , to masculine or both genders , but in Sc . G . to the feminine .

237 acht gé :
simply “ although ” or “ even though ” ; acht ,
as often , has no separate adversative force . Cf . 315 , 380 , acht mura 363 , acht mara 368 “ unless ” , acht mun 1672 , acht mur 2700 .

240 gē bé dā dtug Dia do thidhlocadh bheith eōlach :
lit . “ though there be to whom God has given as a gift to be learned ” , i . e . “ whoever God has given the gift of being learned ” ; bé is pres . subj . of beith .
For predicative do see note 41 .

241 a gceart chanamhna … na Gaoidheilge :
cf . the similar phrases cited in note 230 . That at 366 is a close parallel to the text here , and shows that it can be interpreted as “ expert in the correct form of the language of writing and composing and speaking Gaelic ” , with sgrībhadh and deachtadh treated as synonymous . The other examples give some support to an emended reading a gceart sgrībhaidh agas deachtaidh agas labhartha chanamhna na Gaoidheilge ,
i . e . “ in the correct form of writing , composing , and speaking the Gaelic language ” , with sgrībhadh and deachtadh differentiated to denote orthography and style respectively .

247 mhé :
and also 254 , 384 , in each case as object , as is the solitary example in Des . 800 , cf . p . 360 . For unlenited mé as subject see 380 , 381 , 383 , 388 .

251 lēm bhrāithribh :
I have doubtfully corrected to show the lenition , but its absence can be justified ( cf . Des . xxiii ) , and according to Bergin , IGT iii , is the only correct usage . However , the rule given at IGT Introduction § 52 Lom as cóir do gháoidheilg íad 7 séimh d ’ ogham “ they ought to be pronounced unlenited and written lenited ” , may be cited in extenuation .

257 gurab oide … thú … gurab cádhas … thú … gurab athair … thú :
the pronoun tú is regularly found lenited in independent use , as 411 , 3298 , and as object 880 , while tú is the usual form as the subject pronoun following a verb . Similarly with the emphatic tusa .
The lenition may be inhibited under the usual circumstances of another dental preceding , as tar éis tusa d ’ fhosgladh dhorais dúinn 902 .

258 cádhas :
already at 101 ( paired with onóir ) and 114 ( paired with cúrum and creideamh ) , with the usual sense of “ respect , reverence ” ; here paired with comairce and having the same sense as in CC , i . e . “ refuge , protection ” . Similarly below , 3008 , it is paired with tearmand .

270 ris na h - ūdaraibh :
“ author ” , and also “ an authority ” on some subject ; in the latter sense here , paired with saoi .
A more etymological spelling údhdar ( for úghdar ) at 3493 .

278 acht go mbeith :
“ provided that there was ” ; cf . acht mar 362 “ except as , except in the way that ” .

282 Dia … do choimhēd :
“ may God preserve ” ; neither CDIL , s . v . 1 do 172 . 25 nor Gagnepain , SNV , treats this construction independently or fully . It occurs early , in St . Patrick ’ s Hymn , Thes . II 354 - 8 ( an eight - century composition , cf . Binchy in Eriu XX 235 ) , as 357 . 10 Crist domm imdegail indiu ar neim ar loscud ar bádud ar guin translated “ Christ to protect me today … ” , but in Mael Isu ’ s hymn ( ibid . 359 ) In spirut nóeb d ’ aittreb ar cuirp is ar nanma diar snádud co solma ar gábud ar galra the translation is “ May the Holy Spirit dwell … may He protect us … ” . That the usage is not necessarily a literary or artificial one in Carswell is suggested by its frequent occurrence in the Manx Prayer Book of 1610 , e . g . p . 364 ( a form of absolution ) and Psalm 20 vv . 1 - 5 , but not in the later language . Further examples below at 390 - 4 , 1163 - 8 , and especially in the prayer of his own composition 1402 - 13 .

290 Bīdh amhlaidh :
“ so be it ” , for bīodh .
The foreign “ amen ” is generally translated in BCO , and Carswell has amen only at 3803 , 3965 .

296 do chum an lēghthōir :
Carswell prefers the uninflected gen . sg . here and in Slánuightheóir ,
and this is authorised by IGT Declension § 50 for léghthóir beside the gen . in - óra and that in

299 d ’ fhearaibh Alban agas Eireand :
on the relevance of Eireand here and below see Introduction .

300 briathra dísle Dé :
“ the genuine Word of God ” ; Carswell regularly uses the pl . in this sense , e . g . 558 , 560 , 563 , 568 .

305 acht atā nī cheana :
an introductory formula , prefacing a point to be made , cf . 350 ; also acht cheana 341 , 361 , 375 .

306 atā riamh orainde :
“ which has always been upon us ” ( and still is , whence the present tense ) , i . e . “ from which we have always suffered ” .

311 gan an Bīobla Naomhtha do bheith a gcló Gaoidheilge againd :
“ that we do not possess the Holy Bible printed in Gaelic ” ; the New Testament appeared in Irish in 1602 , and the Old in 1685 , but Gaelic Scotland had to wait until 1767 for the New Testament , and until 1801 for the whole of the Old , partly because of the belief that the Irish version was quite suitable for use in the Highlands , the language of which was usually termed Irish or Erse . For the gen . Gaoidheilge ,
cf . a gcló Laidne 312 .

315 seanchus ar sean nō ar sindsear :
cf . 1316 , and sompladha a sean 7 a sinnsear translating exempla parentum in TSh 5335 .

317 a dtāmhlorgaibh :
cf . Acallamh ( Irische Texte IV i ) 300 , scríbhthar na scéla sin letsa i támhlorguibh filed 7 i mbriathraibh ollaman , 2589 … i tamlorgaib filed 7 a slechtaib suad 7 a mbriathraib ollaman , 3105 … i tamlorgaib filed 7 il - lechtaib fiann ; these examples suggest a standard formula which need have conveyed no very precise impression to the hearer . Stokes , ibid . 274 , explains as “ tablestave ” , a contraction of tabul - lorg , whence CDIL taball .

317 a sleachtaibh :
for the sense “ version ( of a story ) ” , passing over into the sense of “ source ” see CDIL s . v . slicht ( b ) , and Acallamh 2589 quoted above .

319 ar aibrisge agas ar aithghiorra :
the usual meaning of aibrisge is “ brittleness , frailty ” ( so CDIL s . v . aiprisce and Vendryes ’ Lexique s . v . aprisc ) but the synonymous aithghiorra shows that the sense here must be “ quickness ’ . A similar sense is possible in Betha Colaim Chille ( ed . O ’ Kelleher and Schoepperle ) p . 120 . 34 do bi se aibrisc dochum aighte do tabhairt d ’ aes eladhna 7 d ’ filedhaib ; the editors translate “ he was weak in indulging bards and poets ” , but

it might also be rendered “ he had a weakness for giving countenance to ” , and it is easy to see how in this context this might be taken as “ he was quick to show favour ” . The word is not found in any of the Sc . G . dictionaries , but the simplex brisg ,
which in earlier Irish had the same senses as aibrisg ,
has in Sc . G . developed the sense of “ quick ” , and similarly the derivative brisge .

324 ghnāthuidheas siad :
with which goes do chumhdach 329 .

326 ar Thuathaibh Dé Danond , agas ar Mhacaibh Mīleadh , agas ar na curadhaibh , agas ar Fhind mhac Cumhaill :
interesting testimony that in the sixteenth century stories of the mythological cycle , of the fictitious history of the settlement of Ireland , of the Finn cycle , and unspecified heroic tales , perhaps of the Ulster cycle , were circulating and giving pleasure in Gaelic Scotland , and that patrons were still supporting those who could recite them , as well as giving generously to be themselves immortalised in verse . It is one of the less happy aspects of originally alien religious movements like the Reformation and the Methodist revival that in Celtic territory they did so much to discourage the continuance of native tradition and oral literature . There was a lively if not always well - informed correspondence on the Kirk and Gaelic in the columns of “ The Scotsman ” in January and February 1966 .

336 dār n - ainbfios … an drong - sa … :
we might expect dā n - ainbfios ,
i . e . “ of the ignorance of these we have mentioned ” , but Carswell includes himself and his readers in the number of those whose ignorance stems from lack of instruction and good books in their own language . Similarly oraind 338 .

349 do bhí :
the past tense refers to the original book having been drawn up for the English - speaking congregation in exile at Geneva . The progress of the Reformation , both in England and Scotland , had now enabled them to return home .

354 nī rachaind féin a seilbh :
“ I should not myself have undertaken ” ; for dul a seilbh see CDIL s . v . selb 164 . 7 .

362 an Gaill - bhērla :
here , as in 10 , with the original meaning of Bērla as a common noun ( OIr bélre ) “ language ” , and so “ the Lowlanders ’ tongue , English ” . For other meanings see CIL 204 .

367 nī h - a n - Albain amhāin :
“ not only in Scotland ” ; printed here as ni na ,
as on several occasions below , e . g . 900 , 1788 , 1807 . That h - follows ní before even an unstressed vowel is shown by nī h - ar son mhaithis 860 . The passage is interesting as showing that

369 do mhacaibh maithe lēighind :
but mac léighind normally refers to a pupil or student ( cf . CDIL s . v . léigenn 84 . 46 ) , and we might expect d ’ fhearaibh here unless Carswell was misled by some such ambiguity as surrounds English “ scholar ” .

374 mar gach nduine :
for the nasalisation cf . ar gach nduine 1001 , dā gach nduine 3288 .

398 adhmad :
cf . CDIL s . v . admat ( b ) , and Celtica IV 46 . The modern Irish sense of “ material , wood ” , and the Manx ymmyd “ use ” , are later developments .

434 nach bfētar :
impersonal present of fédaim “ I can ” ; the spelling with - t - , which is regular with Carswell , represents what might more etymologically be written fédtar . Cf . DIL s . v . fétaid 100 . 46 .

451 as go mbeith sé :
“ so that it might be ” ; as is apparently a clipped form of iondas ,
frequent in this text , as 684 , 1322 , 2526 , 2603 , 2633 . Perhaps we should compare modern Sc . G os gum bi “ in order that there will be ” , or
’ s in the conjunctions a chum ’ s gu , eagal ’ s gu , ionann ’ s gu ( Calder , Gaelic Grammar § 222 ) .

454 frīth ;
preterite impersonal “ one found ” ; cf . DIL s . v . fo - gaib 226 . 31 .

457 acht Iosa … cland dhīleas do Dhia dhīnde :
‘ but only Jesus Christ our Lord , who , giving us that by grace , which was his by nature , made us through faith the children of God . ’ The words ‘ giving us that by grace ’ and ‘ through faith ’ are not translated , so that ‘ which was his by nature ’ is left without an antecedent . The phrase d ’ fhulang … ndīmhaoinis - ne is Carswell ’ s own addition , “ except that the gracious Jesus of Nazareth should suffer passion and pain for our worthlessness ” , but does not complete the sense , and a line seems to have dropped out at some stage . We might insert after nādúir something like do thabhairt dhúinn lé grás , iondas gurab tré chreideamh do - rinde … ,
making the Gaelic mean “ that he should give us by grace that which was his by nature , so that through faith he has made us true children of God . ”

470 nīrbh ēidir :
preterite of the copula with the predicative éidir ,
and so generally in Carswell , but occasionally spellings with

féidir ,
arising either from the common prosthetic f - or a supposed connection with fédaim ,
occur as at 471 , where nīr is very improbably made to nasalise such a spelling to bfēidir .
As these are the only cases in which bf occurs for etymological bh it is evident that they arise from a false analysis of the source of a sound which could originate equally in the lenition of b and the nasalisation of f . Other instances are 1866 , 1914 , 2255 , and nīor bfada 3240 .

479 crēd tug don thrēigean tú ? :
“ what has caused thee to forsake me ? ” ; the Irish PB version ( Mark 15 . 34 , f . T2 verso ) has créd far thréig tú mhé .

490 ar an treas tráth :
for the meaning “ day ” cf . CDIL s . v . tráth I ( b ) .

493 an da choda … na coda eile :
‘ and therefore without the one we cannot feel the benefit of the other ’ ; accordingly read an dara coda .
For an here cf . CC 234 a 2 a dtimchiol an dara codach ,
and 221 a 1 seadh an dara cuid .

495 fuaramair - ne :
the 1 pl . pret . ends in - amar , but the palatal - ne of the augens sometimes affects the otherwise non - palatal final of the word to which it is suffixed . Cf . ar ar soin - ne 504 , mēdaidh ar gcreidimh - ne 1052 , iondas go bfédaim - ne 3101 .

505 ar chuir :
ar represents the relative preposition a ( nas . ) “ in which ” with ro ,
and occurs again at 1838 ; the usual form in Carswell is inar as at 205 , 2254 , 2946 , ’ nar 716 .

530 ēraic :
originally a payment , specialised in Irish law as a term for legal compensation for injury or death , here used in a rather different and theological sense of ransom or the price paid to redeem .

565 Agas adubhairt an Tighearna féin :
added by Carswell .

574 mar signuidhfear sin :
‘ as it is signified ’ , so that there is no call here for a future , and even if there were we should expect signeóchar ( or cf . CC 81 a 1 shigneobhas ) . The normal spelling would be mar shignighthear ,
with the usual lenition after mar ; the - f - , if not simply a misprint , may be an echo of signify .

575 eidir óg agas tsean :
“ both young and old ” , with the lenition carried forward after agas ,
as in edir anam agas chorp 3929 . The case usage agrees with Des . p . 271 , i . e . singular noun in the accusative , as 70 , 466 , 1897 , and plural noun in the dative as 626 , 780 , 817 ; and also , when a second noun follows after agas it is nominative after the article or a possessive , otherwise dative , as eidir chorp agas anmain 646 , and cf . 1953 - 4 .

618 lucht cumhdaigh agas comh - onōraigh na n - īodhbhal neamh - chosmhail :
‘ against all idolaters ’ ; īodhbhal seems to be a blend of the two words referred to in note 210 . That there was some overlap between the two terms is apparent from CDIL s . v . ídal ( c ) . Neamh - chosmhail occurs only here and at 798 ; there it means “ eccentric , abnormal ” , here perhaps simply “ strange ” .

620 do tharraing as a bfrēmhaibh :
not , as in the different construction of the English , “ to root out ” , but “ who have rooted out ” .

624 Between the mention of the mass and prayer to saints Carswell omits the references to purgatory and limbus patrum , and between prayers for the dead and distinction of meats ( 626 ) he omits the reference to free - will . After seirbhīs īodhalta ( 629 ) he has nothing to correspond to ‘ man ’ s merits , with suchlike , which draw us from the society of Christ ’ s Church , wherein standeth only remission of sins , purchased by Christ ’ s blood to all them that believe , whether they be Jews or Gentiles ’ , and proceeds straight to ‘ vain confidence in creatures and trust in our own imaginations . ’

631 do - bheir Dia cairde agas síneadh :
‘ God … deferreth ’ ; for the latter word cf . CC 371 b 2 dlighidh sé síneadh do chur jonta .

635 daingnithear … lucht na n - olc - sa :
the usual meanings of the verb are “ confirm , strengthen , assure ” , but the English has ‘ they shall be damned ’ , and a future is called for after an uair thiucfas 633 . The choice lies between the f - future damainfithear ( DIL D 66 . 58 ) and , less probably , the e - future daimeóntar . Professor Thomson suggests that though the spelling is assimilated to that of daingniughadh the true source is the loanword that appears in modern Lewis Gaelic in daing ort “ a curse on you ” , and daingit “ dammit ” , both with non - Gaelic d , and to be connected with English dang as a form of damn . It is unfortunately impossible to

641 Tigidh :
similarly gabhaidh 642 , sloindidh 1766 . There is no trace here or in CC of the Sc . G . imperative in - ibh , though it seems certain that it existed before Carswell ’ s time in some areas at least ; cf . Scottish Verse from the Book of the Dean of Lismore , xxiv .

644 go ngairdeachas n - adhbhal :
the only example of go ( nas . ) , preposition with the acc . meaning “ with ” , in this text , though examples of gona “ with its ” are more frequent . Note the nasalisation after the acc . sg . projected on both adjectives .

647 mar a bfaicfeam :
“ where we shall see ” ; cf . CDIL s . v . immar II ( e ) .

653 tré bhioth sīor :
“ for ever ” , from bioth “ world , life ” , as in ar bioth 1820 . Cf . Des . glossary s . v . bioth for evidence of both síor ( acc . ) and shíor ( dat . ) in this phrase .

654 oifige :
so here and at 741 , 760 ( dat . ) , and at 661 , 664 , 686 ( nom . ) . Though not paralleled elsewhere these examples are too numerous to be dismissed as misprints .

658 diosmasaid :
“ dispensation ” , apparently a modified form of the loanword recorded in CDIL s . v . dispensáid ; the nasal of the second syllable seems to have become - m - by assimilation and the - p - then lost and the nasal become syllabic .

666 briathra Dé d ’ fhoillsiughadh :
the English has ‘ in preaching the Word of God and ministering the sacraments . So that in consultations , judgments , elections , and other political affairs , his counsel rather than authority taketh place . ’ Carswell omits the mention of the sacraments here and alters the division of the rest of the sentence to mean “ to proclaim the Word of God in comfortings

679 dona coingheallaibh :
cf . deagh - choinghill agas deigh - bhēsa 683 ; the senses appear to be “ qualifications ” and “ good qualities ” , a development from the sense of “ pledge , guarantee ” , through that of “ distinguishing mark ” .

690 deithneas :
parallel to cūram ,
and so “ eagerness , willingness ” rather than “ haste ” .

701 féchadh … ar an adhbhar ministir :
“ look out for ” gives good sense , with “ examine , look into ” in 708 ; for the use of adhbhar ( like damhna ) as “ the makings of , one fit to be ” cf . CDIL s . v . adbar I ( c ) , and adhbhair an mhinistir 708 .

703 na daoine foirfe :
i . e . the elders ; cf . below 741 - 59 . Originally the participle of for - fen “ finish ” , i . e . foirbthe ,
later spelt foirfe ,
whence the late adjective foirbthech “ aged ” for which , as its only examples , DIL has quotations from Carswell 743 , 769 , 775 . The nom . pl . , despite the spellings in - idhe , - ighe , might imply a noun foirfeach ,
as may the pl . foirfidh in CC 373 b 4 , but the other plural cases cannot do so . An alternative explanation would be to derive the noun from the secondary verb foirbthigidir “ finishes , makes perfect ” , as a spelling of the participle foirfighthe .
Cf . too the noun foirbthidecht “ moral perfection , holiness ” , beside foirbthecht .

708 an bfuil … an a bfuilid :
if an a is not a misprint it may represent a doubling of the interrogative particle an , with a representing the weakened form in which the consonant is lost .

715 gabhaid sgēla a bheatha :
‘ they enquire of his life ’ ; but in the Gaelic the verb is probably imperative , as is the parallel tugaid 719 . Formally beatha can be gen . sg . beathadh ( from beatha “ life ” ) or beatha ( from bioth “ world , age ” ) . The former makes the better sense , and the spelling may be corrected , but cf . note on 1286 .

728 mar :
“ if not , unless ” ; a number of forms and spellings occur , mura bfuil 363 , mara bfuil 368 , mur fhuaidheam agas mur fhīr - cheanglum 531 , mur thograidīs 2383 , mur dhearrna tú 2701 , as well as muna dhearna sé 806 , muna faghthar 2418 , and mun saora tusa 1002 , mun dēntar 1672 , mun roibhe sé 1770 , for which see CDIL s . v . 3 má .

732 tar ēis an mheadhōin laoi :
‘ at afternoon , the sermon ended ’ ; clearly two services are envisaged as this and the phrase do chum na searmōna maidne 729 show . Whereas the BCO has ‘ framing his sermon , or some part therof , to the setting forth of his duty ’ the Gaelic says that part of the morning sermon should relate to the election of the minister .

737 ag cuimhniughadh … :
‘ with request of such things as shall be necessary for his office ’ , but the Gaelic means “ remembering his office according as he is elected . ”

750 eidir siad :
but also eatorra féin 781 “ amongst themselves ” .

751 Ag cruindiughadh … :
in rendering the sentence ‘ In assembling the people , neither they without the ministers , nor the ministers without them , may attempt anything ’ , Carswell has omitted the phrase in italics .

755 maille ré rēsún agas ré toil cháich :
‘ by the consent of the rest ’ . At 2502 résún is similarly paired with tuigse ‘ discretion ’ , in each case with some straining of the meaning .

771 ar eagla go gcaithfidhe daondacht na ndaoine maith … :
‘ having ever a diligent care , that the charity of godly men be not wasted upon loiterers and idle vagabonds ’ , with the italicised

phrase omitted . Note the variety of senses given to daondacht ,
“ humanity ” ( i . e . human - ness ) at 473 - 5 , 1832 , “ humanity ” ( i . e . humane - ness and so charity ) here , and daondacht bheathadh 3871 ( with fascadh ) rendering ‘ harbour ’ , i . e . “ protection , refuge ” . In maithe ,
as originally printed , we have an instance of the common plural form of the adjective being used instead of the specifically gen . pl . one ; cf . na ndaoine easlána 2500 instead of na ndaoine n - easlán ,
and in the Dean of Lismore ’ s Book ban oyga , i . e . ban óga as a gen . pl .

777 Carswell omits the introductory justification for the weekly meeting and proceeds from ‘ it is ordained that every Thursday the ministers and elders in their assembly or consistory … ’ . He has omitted to mention the elders and has added the deacons and the whole congregation , thus transforming what was destined to be the beginnings of presbytery into a congregational meeting .

779 gacha Dar - daoin :
note the adverbial genitive gacha ,
and cf . uair gacha seachtmhuine 810 “ once a week ” .

783 na Phairisidh :
also 2465 , in both cases printed with unlenited p - ; it is uncertain whether this is due to the general reluctance to express the lenition of p - , or whether Carswell preferred a form of the word akin to the Pairisíneach which CDIL quotes from TSh and the Irish New Testament . The lenition is hesitantly adopted in this edition on the perhaps inadequate ground that Sc . G . prefers Phairiseach ,
of which this is the pl .

783 neoch ré bfaicthear :
“ to whom is visible ” , “ who can see ” ; the impersonal is virtually passive here .

792 - 5 In this list Carswell omits ‘ papistry ’ before ‘ schism ’ , sgandail renders ‘ blasphemy ’ , and he reduces ‘ unlawful games , with such like ’ to imbeirt ,
possibly gambling .

799 neamh - chūram … :
‘ negligence , as well in his sermons and in studying the Scriptures , as in all other things concerning his vocation ; scurrility , flattering , lying , back - biting , wanton words , deceit , covetousness , taunting , dissolution in apparel , gesture and other his doings ’ , but Carswell omits the italicised portions , and makes backbiting an offence only when minic .

802 a ngibluibh :
‘ in apparel ’ ; cf . IGT Decl . § 17 gibal , Dinneen giobal , Dwelly gioball ,
but CDIL gibal , i . e . giobhal ;
presumably it is the scarcity of examples collected for CDIL , coupled with the modern Irish usage , that limits the meaning to “ piece of cloth ” .

In the Metrical Psalms ( 1694 ) 102 . 26 we find Biaidh iadsan fòs ar teirachdain / mar ghiobal sean gu léir ; / Feuch claochluigh tù mar thruscan iad ,
in which the parallelism of giobal and truscan shows that Carswell ’ s usage is not eccentric . The Psalms moreover are supposed to be do réir na Heabhra ,
and the Hebrew here is usually translated “ clothing ” .

804 a bfuland :
similarly do fhulaind 1538 , with - nd for - ng .

811 agā mhīniughadh agas agā thuigsin :
the concord is not with cuid ,
but with the nearer noun Sgribhtūir .

816 nī sa mó :
Carswell has ní is before the predicative and adverbial comparatives of other adjectives , as 786 , but regularly nī sa mó and nī sa lia .
The normal contruction is with is , the present of the copula , or better with as ,
its relative form ; sa appears ( CDIL s . v . 7 sa ) to go back to the OIr construction of the “ bigger and bigger ” type , OIr mó assa mó ( GOI § 377 ) , where assa geminates a following consonant , but Keating has ní sa mhó with lenition , as does Carswell at 2092 , 2320 . Ní sa looks like a contamination of these two constructions , but CDIL s . v . 1 ní 40 . 46 assumes níosa is derived directly from ní as . CC has only ni is .

817 eidir thuatadhaibh nó ghaisgeadhachaibh :
see note on 575 . For the first noun see CDIL s . v . túatae , where 348 . 15 under the gloss “ rustic , ignorant person ” the dat . pl . do na tuataighibh is quoted from Donlevy and equated with tuatadhaibh ,
by the editors , while at 348 . 8 we have do na tuataibh “ to the laity ” . For the second see CDIL s . v . gaiscedach “ one bearing arms , a warrior , a champion ” ; this quotation is not used by CDIL in either article . A contrast between the two terms is certain , and “ amongst commonalty or gentry ” fits the sense best .

831 a bfiadhnuise do chumhachtaibh diadha - sa :
“ before thy divine majesty ” , a regular meaning of cumhachta in Carswell , e . g . 964 .

834 a bpeacadh … :
the whole series of five nouns corresponds to ‘ in sin and iniquity ’ , and the words ‘ so that in us there is no goodness ’ are not translated .

849 atāmaoid … agad ghuidhe - se :
the development of this characteristically Scottish ( and early Manx ) construction is attri -

buted ( ID 132 ) to the acquisition of future meaning by the present - tense forms , which in turn depends ( ID 222 ) on the reduction of the f - formative of the future to - h - , followed by the dialectal loss of the - h - . See now Professor Greene ’ s criticism of this approach in Proceedings of the Second International Congress of Celtic Studies 1963 ( Cardiff , 1966 ) 135 - 6 . The argument is in any case applicable only to verbs having an f - future : in the irregular verbs it is the Irish present that corresponds formally to the Scottish Gaelic and Manx future , and it would be more natural to expect one and the same process to apply to all verbs . Cf . CDIL s . v . oc 82 . 55 - 64 and III . Carswell usually has the shortened forms
’ gud ,
with
’ gut before a vowel .

861 an lā bhudh fhearr iad :
“ the day that they were best ” , i . e . “ even at their best ” .

864 tugabhair :
2 pl . preterite , here a plural of respect .

874 ris an Mac mōr mīorbhuileach :
cf . 292 , where a hyphen might be inserted ; but as it stands each noun has two alliterating epithets and the same consideration applies here , confirmed by the absence of lenition in the second adjective . But at 1406 it is necessary to admit the compound adjective .

889 ar gcoinsiasa :
and so normally , as in Des . and CC , but occasionally with - n - restored . It seems to have ousted the native MIr cubus almost entirely . The compounded form of the latter , however , co - cubus ( CIL ) , is found in TSh and the Irish Prayer Book in the form cogúas , and in Sc . G . as cogais .

905 an Rīoghacht :
i . e . Scotland . Note the concord a n - aingidheachta and do ghnāthuidheadar 906 - 7 , which are with the plural notion “ the inhabitants of Scotland ” .

908 na bPriondsadh :
the first edition of BCO has “ Princess ” here , a reference to Queen Mary , later changed to “ Princes ” , as in Carswell .

919 ar bfaicsin dúinn go … :
“ when we saw that … ” , but there is nothing corresponding in the English and the phrase , which Carswell uses several times , is rather “ seeing that … ” as a causal conjunction ; cf . 1314 , 2897 , 2944 . The English construction appears to date from the early sixteenth century , but even when it stands in his original Carswell does not always imitate it : cf . ar dtuigsin dúinn go ndearrna an Tighearna an uiread - sin do thrōcaire oraind ‘ seeing

that our Lord has dealt thus mercifully with us ’ 2196 ; similarly 2200 , and ō tāid na h - uile chrēatūire ’ gut aithne ‘ seeing that all creatures do acknowledge thee ’ 2248 . A particularly clear case is ar bfaicsin duit - se gurab í do thoil ‘ seeing that it hath pleased thee ’ 2607 , where “ when you saw that it was your will ” would be absurd . Literal meaning at 1741 .

923 ag cur at adhaigh :
‘ rebel ’ , a rather stronger sense than that of “ oppose ” or “ contradict ” found in TSh and Des . Cf . gan chur ’ na h - adhaidh 1345 .

931 an tan … d ’ allmhurrchuibh :
Carswell omits ‘ by our foolishness ’ .

933 nī fhuil comhnuidhe ort … acht ag toirbheart :
“ thou ceasest not to give ” .

940 an chomhdāil chogaidh :
‘ the whispering of sedition ’ ; Gaelic rather “ mustering for battle ” , though comhdhāil could perhaps mean “ plotting ” .

944 doineand agas droch - tsīona na h - aimsire :
the lines 939 to 947 are marked in BCO ‘ These clauses … may be used , or any of them as occasion serveth ’ in a marginal note , so that there need be no specific reference intended by their inclusion in the Gaelic version . Calderwood ( II 248 ) says : In Januarie ( 1564 ) , upon the 20th day therof , the rain falling freezed so vehementlie , that the ground was like a shott of yce . The fowles of the aire deed , and might not flee . In the same moneth the sea stood still , neither flowing nor ebbing the space of twentie - foure houres .

947 lom - lán : lom could at the best have only an intensive force in this compound , but even so its meaning is too nearly the opposite of lán ;
according to CDIL s . v . lomnán , lom - lán is not what it seems , but a form of imlán .

967 buaidh dtroda :
“ victory ” , with troda ,
gen . of troid “ fight ” as at 816 ; the exceptional nasalisation occurs because buaidh is acc . sg . or even because it was once neuter .

979 ag dēnamh umhla agas prósdāla :
‘ we prostrate ourselves ’ ; prosdáil is noted in CDIL N - O - P 207 . 73 from this passage only . It also occurs below 2591 .

979 a bfiadhnuise do chathrach cumhachtaighe - se :
‘ before the

throne of thy majesty ’ ; cf . note 831 . Carswell apparently makes no distinction between cathair “ city ” and cathaoir “ throne ” ; for the gen . sg . of the latter Keating ( TSh 6799 ) has cathaoireach .

981 fīor - allmhurrdha :
cf . 1006 allmhurraidh .
The foreigners are , of course , the French , expelled in July 1560 .

984 rīoghruidh :
not strictly the pl . of rí ,
for which Carswell has rīghthe 83 , but a fem . sg . collective ríoghradh ,
whence the gen . sg . na rīghruidhe Albanuidhe 28 , and similarly 179 , 1206 . The nom . sg . here with the form of the acc . - dat . occurs also in a passage of Keating ( TSh 7875 ) . Cf . too the Sc . G . pl . rìghre , rìghrean .

992 atá … ar lán - līonadh :
“ have filled ” ; on the history of the periphrastic perfect with ar ( from iar ) with a verbal noun , a typically East Gaelic feature , see ID 135 , 234 - 5 . In Carswell , as in early Manx and on its rare appearances in Irish , ar nasalises . Further examples at 1189 , 1442 .

1008 gidh bé mar tá :
equivalent to gé tá .

1010 ar son ghlōire th ’ anma féin :
