gen . sg . of ainm here and at 1325 , but Carswell has identical forms for the gen . sg . and gen . pl . ( anmand ) of both ainm and anam .
The gen . sg . ainme seems to be a later creation .

1012 eadruind :
“ amongst us ” ; similarly eadraind 1016 .

1014 iondas go bfeicfidh an saoghal … agas go dtuigidh gach aon :
“ that all the world may know ” ; for such pairings of future and present subjunctive see the Introduction .

1024 atāmaoid … dār lēigean féin … agas ag ar dtoirrneamh :
cf . note 215 . For toirrneamh see CDIL s . v . tairniud .
from the same source in the Metrical Psalms ( 1659 ) 18 . 32 Se Dia a fphasgas me le neart , / is ni mo shlighe re .

1032 i ndeigh - ithir : ithir is etymologically “ cornland ” , from ith ;
cf . iothlann .

1037 inar n - iarratasaibh :
M ’ L read the original as mar , but I read the facsimile of the Pierpont Morgan copy as inar . Professor Matheson suggested um ar , which would be a palaeographically straightforward correction , though um occurs only once elsewhere in the text . Carswell generally uses fá to introduce this kind of phrase , e . g . fā spioraid an ghliocais … do neartughadh … and 30 - 32 , aontadhach … fā chūrsadh do dhēnamh 672 , fāna daoinibh … d ’ iompōdh 1073 , fā chroidhe gach uile rīogh … do chongbhāil 1090 - 92 , fād thrōcaire … d ’ fhoillseachadh 1117 , fād tseirbhīs … do dhēnamh 1346 , and fár n - iarratasaibh is what we should expect here . As this is a construction in which fo has displaced imm ( cf . DIL s . v . fo 173 . 67 - ) it may be that we should read mar and analyse it as imm + ar , with apocope .

1043 a bfēgmhuis do chuidigh - se :
so too at 2546 , but more correctly cuidighthe 1120 , and most commonly cuidighe 251 etc . It may be significant that both these shortened forms have the augens - se .

1052 Mēdaidh ar gcreidimh - ne :
see note 495 .

1076 go nglan - tuigsin t ’ fhīrinde neamhdha - sa :
‘ to the pure understanding and knowledge of thy heavenly truth ’ ; cf . note 644 for go n -
“ with ” , but this is ruled out here by the context , and n - must be an error .

1093 agas go h - āiridhe … :
from here to 1104 we have an insertion in BCO ( Laing VI 298 ) replacing the prayers for the city of Geneva in the first version ( Laing IV 183 - 4 ) .

1096 ar mBanrīoghna agas ar bPriondsa :
i . e . Queen Mary and the future James VI .

1097 futhadh :
cf . futhaibh 1218 , and DIL s . v . fo 167 . 45 - 53 . The first of these forms is the original accusative ( with unhistorical - dh ) , the second the original dative , but without distinction of sense . Cf . note 1277 .
1114 After fā dheōidh a short passage of the Geneva Book was struck out in BCO . M ’ L prints the original text on p . 69 ‘ And as we be bound … destroy thy flock . ’ BCO then proceeds , ‘ And
finally , O Lord God , most merciful Father , we most humbly beseech thee to show thy great mercies … ’ .

1132 For another text of the Lord ’ s Prayer see 1574 - 80 , and cf . CC p . 71 for a very similar rendering , differing chiefly in the use of augentia , and with pl . for sg . neamh , naomhtha for beandaighthe ,
and cíulan for lēig .
The Irish Prayer Book version , f . A2 , runs : Ar nathairne atá ar neamh , náomhthar thainmsi . Tigeadh do righachd . Déntar do thoil , ar talmhain amhuil do níthear ar neamh . Tabhair dhuinn aniu ar narán laoitheamhuil , 7 maith dhuinn ar bfhiacha , amhuil mhaithmidne dár bfhéitheamhnaibh féin . Agus na tréoraigh chum buaigheartha sinn , achd sáor sinn ó nolc . The final doxology does not occur . At 1132 go mo is a dittography for go ma ;
1133 dod ríghe ,
but correctly do at 1575 .

1146 With this version of the Creed cf . CC p . 4 ; the differences are again slight : the insertion of do crochadh in CC , go hifreand instead of a n - ifreand , do éirghidh ó bhas a gciond an treas lá , atá anois na shuidhe , comhchoitchionn for go h - uilidhe , cumand , marthanach for suthain .
Both agree on eisēirghe cholla ( or chodla ) na marbh .
The CC version is extremely close to and probably derived from the Irish Prayer Book f . B2 verso , with which it agrees wherever it differs from Carswell except for the Prayer Book ’ s ó mharbhuibh ( = ó bhás ) , shuidheas ( = atā … na shuidhe ) ,
and éiseirghe na colla ( = eiséirghe chodla na marbh ) .

1154 tiucfas :
CC thiocfas ,
but Irish Prayer Book tiocfas .

1156 andsa Sbiorad :
in no version of this last sentence is the preposition repeated before each noun in turn .

1158 colla :
by assimilation from colna ,
gen . sg . of colann .

1161 na Psalm :
“ a Psalm ’ , but the Gaelic has the plural .

1163 dār mbeandachadh :
cf . note 282 . In the Gaelic the pronouns are 1st . pers . pl . , in the English 2nd . pers . pl . in the Geneva Book ( Laing IV 185 ) , but 1st . pl . in BCO ( Laing VI 298 ) .

1167 a tsīthchāimhe :
“ his peace ” ; Carswell has the more familiar sīothchāna at 488 ( in the sense of “ reconciliation ” ) . This form may represent a compound of the synonyms síoth and támh ,
but in view of the other form of the gen . sg . na gnáth - tsíthchāine 3863 , this may be only a misprint .

1177 atāmaoid :
perhaps more correctly ó támaoid ( cf . 1531 note ) , and so parallel to ó dho gheallais 1175 , though in the English “ since ” is not repeated .

1182 atámaoid … 1192 atámaoid … :
‘ we , therefore , … we , I say , … ’ ; the subject has become unduly separated from the main verb and makes a fresh start .

1187 an mhéid agas atá … :
‘ forasmuch as our faith is grounded … ’ ; but usually after an ( or in ) mhéid agas Carswell has go ,
as go raibhe 469 , 845 , and go bfuilmaoid 1067 .

1200 do rēir :
dat . of riar :
as a phrase - preposition usually “ according to ” , “ as regards ” ( cf . dā rēir sin 1215 “ accordingly ” ) , but here in the sense “ obedient to ” ; cf . CDIL s . v . I ríar 59 . 3 .

1210 ó aimsir go h - aimsir :
here , as at 1240 , exactly renders the English ‘ from time to time ’ , and has the sense that it then had , viz . “ continually ” , a usage confined , according to NED , to the sixteenth century . At 1312 where the English phrase recurs , Carswell has gach én - lā .
For another example of the sense “ continually ” , cf . the Irish Prayer Book f . FFf verso , ar míghníomha ró iomdha , noch dho rindeamar go ró adhúathmhar ar feadh ar mbheatha uile “ our manifold sins and wickedness , which we from time to time most grievously have committed ” .

1243 na mac - dtīre :
“ of the wolves ” ; cf . 1299 and CDIL s . v . mac 7 . 60 .

1253 do bhí roimhe so a láimh :
‘ have been hitherto holden captive ’ .

1260 na daoine dā dtugais do ghrāsaibh … do bhriathar :
‘ they whom thou hast already endued with thy grace , and illuminated their hearts with the knowledge of thy word ’ ; but the Gaelic is rather “ those to whom thou hast granted by grace that their hearts should be illuminated and opened to understand thy word ” . Do ghrāsaibh is “ by grace ” not “ thy grace ” , since Carswell never elsewhere uses the - ibh ending except for the dat . pl . Cf . Calder ,
Gaelic Grammar , pp . 79 - 80 . If one wishes to retain ‘ thy ’ , then dod ghrāsaibh would be an easy correction .

1270 triobalōid :
but gen . sg . trioblōide 1108 , and triobhlōid 1603 . The - a - may be a svarabhakti vowel , but the - bh - has some historical justification ; cf . CDIL s . v . treblait , whence MIr treabhluid , and also triblóid , a later borrowing of Latin tribulatio , as shown by the unlenited - b - , but with the suffix assimilated to that of words like OIr oróit , tríndóit , in which the - ó - reflects the British rounding of Celtic and Latin ā , and so marks them as taken from Latin orātio , trinitātem , through British . Since the evidence thus associates - ó - with unlenited - b - , it seems proper to correct to trioblōid at 1603 , but this spelling may also represent the older treabhlaid , ? triobhlaid .

1271 amhgar :
so here and at 1275 , but amhghar 1297 and thereafter . Dinneen , TSh , Des . have amhgar , and Modern Irish angar , but Dwelly only àmhghar .

1275 corparrdha :
cf . corparradha 1921 , against the usual corporrdha .

1277 tabhairt orrtha … 1278 teacht orrthuibh … 1280 tabhairt orthuibh :
similarly foillsigh … orra 1591 , but foillsiughadh do ghrāidh orthuibh 1599 ; orrtha , orra ( OIr forru ) is the acc . form , orthuibh ( OIr foraib ) the dat . A distinction of form remains but not one of meaning .

1286 na n - Ainteadhcrīosd :
it is not clear why Carswell here uses the gen . pl . , but elsewhere , 620 , 1616 ( the same phrase as here ) the sg . The spelling is very variable and the omission of t - at 2937 suggests that the word was not very well established in Gaelic . For other examples cf . CDIL s . v . Ainticríst .

1286 uireasbhuidh beatha :
‘ lack this food of life ’ ; Carswell uses biadh ,
gen . bídh for “ food ” but also occasionally beatha ,
gen . beathadh ,
e . g . 172 ( with reference to manna ) , at 3808 , and 3830 biadh agar beatha .
Cf . CIL s . v . betha ( 2 ) . For Carswell the - dh of the gen . sg . seems to have been silent , for he uses beatha as gen . at 715 note , 1913 , 1919 , and no doubt here too . After the nom . fem . sg . we should expect bheathadh .

1295 cumhanta :
gen . of the verbal noun cungnamh , congnamh “ help ” .

1299 na madadh - alta :
“ wolves ” , lit . wild dogs .

1302 fā dheōidh :
although these words come at the end of a paragraph which ends in the middle of a line at the bottom of the

page in the original edition , so that there is no ambiguity about the sentence division , they should probably have been printed on the line below as a catchword to be repeated at the head of f . F2 , for the new paragraph opens ‘ Finally , O Lord God , … ’ .

1304 an mhéid atamaoid :
cf . the current Irish Prayer Book ( 1965 ) p . 9 an mhéid atá anseo i láthair “ as many as are here present ” , and the Scottish book ( 1794 ) pp . 2 , 14 a mheid ’ s ata ’ n so lathair ,
but not the Irish book of 1609 . See too an mhéid do - rindeamar … d ’ ēgōir 1408 “ all the iniquity we have done ” . Cf . CDIL s . v . méit II ( e ) .

1307 agas do chomaoineachadh a Chuirp :
in BCO there is a marginal note ‘ If the Lord ’ s Supper be ministered , then is here added this clause : And to celebrate his holy Supper ’ .

1315 nach maireand :
- and was in Irish the conjunct present ending , eventually ousting the independent - idh ( ID 132 ) , and although general in Carswell and CC has not survived in East Gaelic . There is no trace in Manx , and in Sc . G . it survives only in this phrase nach maireand “ the late ” , lit . “ who does not survive ” . The structural ambiguity of maireann in this phrase led to its being construed as an adjective once the verbal form had become obsolete , and it is so used in Metrical Psalm 61 . 6 Saogh ’ l maireann agus aimsir chian .
For the verb cf . CDIL s . v . maraid .

1325 is oighri ar gach ēn - onōir é :
‘ as it is worthy of all honour ’ ; an unusual spelling ( perhaps for oirigh ,
or influenced by oighre “ heir ” ) for airidhe ,
for which see note 41 . The last section of this prayer is based on the petitions of the Lord ’ s Prayer , as is indicated marginally in BCO .

1332 agā n - áirthear thú :
‘ in such sort that thou mayest be counted ’ ; agā n - can only be the relative form of the prep . ag , i . e . “ at whom ” or “ by whom ” , but we have to go too far back in the sentence to find a plausible antecedent for this to be a likely interpretation . In view of the English it seems more likely that we should correct aga n - to as go n - . The verb áirthear is apparently to be taken as from the verbal noun áireamh ,
stem áirmh - , as in 1st . pers . sg . present āirbhim and 2nd . sg . preterite do áirimh tú ;
the - mh - is also omitted in the impersonal conditional áirfidhe ,
but this is understandable before - f - . The loss of - mh - in the present impersonal is harder to justify , and we may emend the text to read as go n - áirmhthear thú .

1334 cloidheamh :
but ‘ sceptre ’ in BCO .

1367 atāmuid ’ gud ghuidhe - se … :
‘ we beseech thee , pardon us our innumerable offences … and forgive us so freely that death and sin may hereafter have no title against us . ’ Some such phrase as agas maith dhúinn go saor ,
might be inserted after imarcacha to correspond to the English but it is not necessary to the sense or the grammar and only repeats the idea of the previous phrase .

1377 sgáth agas díon agas dīdin :
‘ wealth ’ , in the older sense of “ good , profit , advantage ” .

1387 lēd t ’ intind :
cf . dod t ’ eadar - ghuidhe - se 2545 , dod honorughadh - sa 3176 , for a similar double expression of the possessive .

1389 fearrdha :
i . e . feardha ,
adjective from fear ;
for the - rr - see note 1 .

1402 d ’ fhosgladh agas d ’ fhoillsiughadh :
cf . ar gcroidheadha d ’ fhoillsiudhadh 2913 ‘ lighten our hearts ’ ; Carswell elsewhere uses foillsiughadh to mean “ show , illustrate , proclaim , reveal , preach ” , all of which are consistent with its derivation from follus .
Here we should expect rather soillsiughadh ,
but in neither of these places is emendation on the basis of f misread for long s possible , for then we should also have to correct d ’ to do , and in this passage we should also spoil the alliteration .

1410 do lēigean lind gan dīoghaltus :
cf . TSh glossary s . v . léigim le “ allow one to have ” .

1434 ag dēnamh fhiadhnuise [ ’ nar n - adhaidh] :
‘ bear witness against us ’ .

1447 gach mēid mar mhothuidhemuid … is mōide dhlighmuid … :
‘ the more we feel … so much the more we should … ’ ; for

this use of gach méid cf . CDIL s . v . méit III ( d ) . Móide is mó plus de “ more on that account ” and so “ the more ” , sometimes treated by Sc . G . grammarians as an extra degree of comparison , e . g . Calder , Gaelic Grammar § 94 , “ second comparative ” .

1450 do mhōr - thrōcaire - se sin :
“ that great mercy of thine ” , with both possessive do ( and augens - se ) and demonstrative sin .
The combination of these two is not common in Gaelic ( cf . CDIL s . v . 1 sin I ( d ) , but is quite spontaneous here as the English has ‘ thy sovereign bounty ’ .

1477 gur thimpōidheamar :
normally the verbal noun is impódh rather than the late timpódh ( on which see CDIL s . v . do - immpói ) , condemned by IGT Verbs § 64 , but here required by the alliteration with tilleadh .
Forms of this verb are found in the Irish Linguistic Atlas , map 178 , at points 56 - 9 , 61 , 69 , 70 , 76 - 7 ; does this give a clue to where in Ireland Carswell or his bardic teachers might have studied ?

1478 a lenmhuin :
a may be the equivalent of do or ag ,
but probably the former , as a ’ for ag is normal in Carswell only before velars .

1480 dot th ’ ainm :
even in the original spelling hainm we have a double possessive here , as in ad t ’ athair and ad t ’ fhear - dídin 3113 . When not lenited , t ’ is the usual prevocalic form , and similarly - t in combination with prepositions , but - d before consonants ( though not invariably , e . g . 1333 , 1481 ) . It makes little difference whether we write dot ainm or do t ’ ainm ,
but the analogy of the forms written before consonants , as dod ghliocas 1125 , lēd bhriathruibh 1484 , suggests we should prefer dot .

1515 do thuill siad - san … do thuilleadar - san :
synonymous analytic and synthetic verbal forms , presumably as a stylistic variation .

1519 ar n - aodhaire :
more correctly aoghaire ,
cf . CDIL s . v . oegaire ; etymologically speaking “ shepherd ” as distinct from “ cowherd ” , i . e . buachaill ,
though here paired with the latter .

1522 fā dheōidh :
should follow the next agas , i e ‘ finally , because thou art our God ’ ; cf . note 1302 .

1531 ō tāmaoid :
printed atamaoid ,
but BCO has ‘ considering that we call ’ ; cf . too note 1177 .

1542 na coinsiansa ar a bfuil eire :
printed na gcoinsiansa a bfuil eire ,
but BCO has four parallel phrases , viz . ‘ the heavy souls and comfortless , the humble hearts , the consciences oppressed and

laden with the grievous burden of their sins , and [who] therefore thirst after thy grace . ’ Alternatively we could read
’ na gcoinsiansaibh ar a bfuil eire ,
parallel to
’ na gcroidheadhaibh umhla ,
as Carswell seems to have intended to make some change in the English construction .

1550 nī raibhe do thruime nō do mhēd a bpeacadh :
‘ were their enormities and sins never so grievous ’ ; cf . note 149 .

1553 gur impāidh tú :
cf . CDIL : s . v . imm - sói for - ái - as well as Carswell ’ s usual - ói - . The - o - is never marked long and if Carswell did not pronounce it so it would not matter whether he wrote - aidh or - oidh or - uidh , for all would sound - í or possibly - ich . Since in Sc . G . this is identical with verbs having - achadh as their verbal noun , the modern form is iompachadh .

1562 chumairce agas chuimridhe :
‘ refuge ’ ; beside cumairce Carswell also has comairce 258 , but not coimirce as in TSh . The gen . sg . cuimridhe is obscure ; it seems most likely to be the abstract from Dwelly ’ s cuimreach “ assistant ” ( quoted from Armstrong ’ s Supplement ) , i . e . cuimrighe .
Dinneen gives coimrighe , comraighe , merely as variant forms of coimirce ; Dwelly has coimirc and coimric .

1595 rē plaidh … lē tindeas … :
two cases of ré and four of lé ,
all parallel and with the same meaning . There is extensive confusion of the prepositions representing OIr fri and la in later Irish , and to a lesser extent in some forms of Sc . G . and Manx . Cf . in the note on 2163 the Irish maille ré creideamh … agus lé dóchus , lé plághaibh agus ré gallraighthibh ,
and below maille rēna … agas lēna … 2938 .

1604 sobrōin :
antonym of dobrón ,
and so paired with subhachas ;
since the simplex here is brón “ grief ” it is surprising that it takes no more than the ameliorative prefix so - to turn it into “ pleasure ” . The re - formation so - bhròn quoted by Dwelly from Armstrong gives more nearly the sense we might expect . Cf . CDIL s . v . 2 so - 309 . 15 for another example , and for the pairing of the corresponding adjectives , see IT IV i 2457 subach sobrónach .

1610 do nāmhad agas nāmhad t ’ fhīrinde :
but ‘ of their enemies and thine ’ .

1625 toirmisge :
‘ not permitted ’ ; similarly written at 803 . Cf . CDIL s . v . do - airmesca 192 . 21 , tairmisgthe with - th - inserted editorially ; a phonetic rather than an etymological spelling .

1629 mar phiseōgaibh nō mar ghliocas :
‘ as charms or sorceries ’ ; that such misuse of the consecrated bread was a real danger is confirmed by the final rubric in the Communion Order in the First Prayerbook of Edward VI ( 1549 ) : “ And although it be read in ancient writers , that the people many years past received at the priest ’ s hands the Sacrament of the body of Christ in their own hands , and no commandment of Christ to the contrary ; yet forasmuch as they many times conveyed the same secretly away , kept it with them , and diversely abused it to superstition and wickedness ; lest any such thing hereafter should be attempted , and that an uniformity might be used throughout the whole realm , it is thought convenient the people commonly receive the Sacrament of Christ ’ s body in their mouths , at the priest ’ s hand . ” Other counsels prevailed , however , and from the Second Prayerbook ( 1552 ) onwards the rubric prescribes administration “ to the people in their hands . ”

1630 a bfāgbhāil :
printed abfaghail ,
but renders ‘ left [i . e . entrusted] to the congregation . ’

1631 mar tséla aithrighe :
“ as seals of repentance ” , but ‘ as seals of the same [i . e . the Word] ’ .

1635 an fhiadhnuise :
“ the witness ” , but ‘ god - father ’ ; similarly 1766 for ‘ surety ’ , but for ‘ god - father ’ 1771 Carswell has an t - athair spioratālta .

1648 cland ochta :
‘ children by adoption ’ , cf . 1792 and CC 366 c 2 mac ochta ,
and 46 b 2 macacht ochta .
In CDIL s . v . ucht 50 . 33 the only sense of mac ochta is “ dear son ” , like English “ bosom friend ” . The Scottish use as “ adopted son ” may imply some contrasting phrase such as mac bronn ,
or it may be influenced by the occurrence of phrases like do ghabh … Crīosd chuige … ’ na ucht an chland bheag 1667 , and ag faicsin bhur gcloinde agā ngabhāil a n - ucht an choimhthinōil 1741 .

1651 céim :
‘ generation ’ ; cf . Shorter Catechism 1659 ( CC , p . 248 ) go nuige an treas no an ceathramh cem no glun ghinealuigh ,
which is only a slightly modernised version of Carswell ’ s own translation in his catechism , below 3438 . The words go nuige an mīle céim correspond to gus an mhíle genealach CC 155 b 3 , and arise from an interpretation which understood “ thousands ” to refer to generations , not to individuals . Carswell in the catechism ( like the Irish Prayer Book , LLL 2 verso , from which CC 217 b derives ) does not

follow this interpretation but has trócaire dona míltibh don druing agā mbia mo ghrádh 3439 . Note the absence of a distinct ordinal form in an mīle céim ;
CDIL s . v . míle has no examples of this use , but only a single one s . v . mílmad . The English has ‘ unto the thousand generation ’ , where thousand is both cardinal and ordinal , the modern thousandth being an analogical re - formation ; cf . NED s . v . thousand 4 , and , for a parallel , eighth , quotations 1477 - 1609 .

1652 an ghearraidh - thimchill :
similarly teascadh - timchill 3715 ; in such a compound timcheall ( so spelt regularly in Carswell , timchiol in CC ) is adverbial , but in these cases it is made gen . as if the object of gearradh and teascadh .
CDIL has no examples of these compounds , but s . v . timchell has both t . - gerrad and t . - tescad . The Manx giarey - chymmylt , with subsequent development of the meaning “ foreskin ” for chymmylt ( cf . Journal of the Manx Museum VII 63 ) , is the closest parallel available .

1661 ach :
the only instance of the modern form in contrast to Carswell ’ s usual acht ,
and presumably an oversight . ID 269 notes that ach is found in fifteenth - century Irish manuscripts ; it is also the form in the earliest Manx , and is found in the Dean of Lismore ’ s Book .

1665 athair :
but ‘ either of the parents ’ in the Geneva Book .

1668 an chland bheag :
also 1670 , with singular adjective in strict concord , but plural pronouns iad , leō .

1669 gurab do phobal Dé an chland bheag :
‘ that infants be of the number of God ’ s people . ’

1675 deifriughadh :
“ haste ” ; historical spelling deithbhriughadh .

1686 ar gcēdfadh tromdhoi - ne :
‘ our dull senses ’ ; cf . notes 495 , 1052 for this effect of - ne . Similarly ar nádūir dhaonnai - ne 1837 , ar ndeagh - bheathai - ne 3292 .

1692 puindsiūn :
cf . CC 262 b 7 and note . Professor Greene observes that - n - appears also in the Old Spanish form ponçoña ( SGS X 247 ) , but this is too remote a source to be likely , and the ending in - ūn points clearly to Norman French . The - n - is intrusive and late , the source being Latin potionem ( cf . J . Corominas , Diccionario Crítico Etimológico da la Lengua Castellana , s . v . ponzoña ) and it is probably no more than a coincidence that it should occur sporadically in the Romance languages and in Scottish Gaelic ; there seem to be no examples in NED .

1694 deasgaidh :
“ dregs ” ; on the various forms of the word see

CDIL s . v . descad . Dwelly gives deasgadh m . and deasgainn f . , but it seems to be f . here to judge from the pronoun í 1956 , which should , according to the English , refer to deasgaidh ,
and not , as it may in the Gaelic , to droch - nādūir .

1713 umarcach :
usually i ( o ) marcach ;
cf . umchubhaidh 2242 beside the usual imchubhaidh ,
and perhaps iumad 1465 beside imad ,
and iumchur 3271 beside iomchur .

1714 agas an sgiath daingean do - leōnta a n - adhaidh bháis agas ifrind :
GB has only ‘ against sin , death and hell ’ , the rest “ and the firm impenetrable shield ” being Carswell ’ s own .

1738 nī bhus furachra do rēir ar n - inmhe :
‘ more warily in our vocation ’ ; cf . the positive fuireachair 1749 . Inmhe also means “ wealth , rank ” , but here probably no more than “ the state we are in ” as revealed by the self - examination referred to in 1729 - 33 . For another rendering of “ vocation ” cf . 1803 .

1744 neoch agā bfuil a úidh :
“ who have his attention ” ; for neoch as a relative cf . note 63 .

1746 is beite dhaoibh - se subhachas sīor - bhuan oraibh :
‘ it ought greatly to rejoice you ’ . Cf . is beite dhaoibh - se fuireachair 1749 “ you must be careful ” , and nī h - ion - bhethe dhúinne uaimhneach CC 87 a 1 “ we need not be afraid ” , in both of which the subject of the finite verb becomes agent with the non - finite verb . It is interesting to note that when the subject is a noun and the complement a personal pronoun in the finite construction , as atá a fhios agaibh ,
then in the non - finite construction the complement becomes agent and the noun remains subject , e . g . is beite dhībh a dheirbh - fhios agaibh 2413 , is beite dhaoibh a dheirbh - fhios agaibh 2478 , not is beite dā fhios agaibh .
Similarly here , and in cases like is ēidir lind a dheirbh - fhios do bheith againd 2204 , rēr chóir dhúinn th ’ eagla do bheith oraind 2964 ‘ whereby we have occasion to fear thee ’ , and bhus éidir leó náire dá ngabháil 3293 ‘ they may be ashamed ’ .

1761 a lán - ndóchas do dhēnamh as fīrēntacht Iosa Crīosd :
cf . ag dēnamh neamh - dhōchais as maitheas Dé 2190 ; as is properly a pronominal form , displacing the older a before a noun . Carswell has a in dōchas … a creatūiribh 630 , and 3430 - 1 ( where it is also found in CC 136 b ) , and a h - before a vowel in 165 , 1359 .

1776 go madh feirrde :
i . e . fearr + de ,
with the palatalisation extended to the - rr - ; cf . note 1447 .

1777 roindfeam :
‘ we shall divide ’ , which calls for the correction of roind ,
which may be a dittography from 1775 .

1784 gurab é Dia … :
“ that he is our Father , Almighty , maker of heaven and earth ” ; the original has only commas where we have printed semicolons , and rather than assume that Carswell has confused the numbering of the items , we should perhaps admit the otherwise unlikely possibility that the numbers follow the items , and so punctuate — uile - chumhachtach , an dara ní ; gurab é … talmhan é , an treas nī ; goirmaoid … .

1796 nō comhfhurtacht crīochnuighe :
‘ nor final joy ’ ; on formal grounds críochnuighthe ,
more correctly so spelt , may be either participle or gen . of the verbal noun . There appear to be examples of comhfhurtacht in Carswell both as m . , as here and 1929 , and f . as 1597 , but all depend on an absence of lenition which may be incorrect .

1804 ar nglōruighthe :
‘ our glorification ’ ; the original ar nglanta is a dittography from the preceding line .

1852 gan chion fir :
Carswell ’ s addition “ without the love of a man ” ; cf . gan chomand no chomhchaidreamh fir CC 50 b 6 .

1863 agā bfuil cóir … ar ladh … do chuma … do rēir choinsiasa daonna :
‘ that hath just authority and power to make laws to bind the consciences of men ’ ; do rēir in a very general sense “ with regard to ” , as 1946 .

1868 agas oibrighe sé so :
‘ and this he doeth ’ ; i . e . oibrighidh ,
but probably pronounced oibrí .

1877 gidh bé iarras … do - bheirid :
‘ whosoever seeketh … they do not only blaspheme … ’ , with faulty concord in BCO also . Cf . féchadh … gach aon - duine … agas dā ndēnaid mur sin , ithid … agas ōlaid 2134 , but gidh bē īosas no ōlfas … īosaidh agas ōlfaidh sé … do chiond nach dtug sé aire 2136 .

1880 go fiú a gcumhachta :
‘ as far as in them is ’ ; cf . go feadh mo chumhachta 44 , and DIL s . v . fíu 159 . 3 .

1888 go h - aithghearr :
‘ chiefly ! Read go h - áraidhe ?

1902 crochaidhe :
‘ hanged ’ or “ hanging ” here , ‘ hanged on us ’ , i . e . “ hung on us , attached to us ” below 1907 . The participle of crochadh is crochta ;
that of crochughadh would be crochaighthe ,
but no such verb seems to be recorded . Professor Thomson informs me

that in his Lewis dialect the participle of crochadh is crochait ( e ) ,
which recalls the normal Manx participle in - it ; in that case , however , the earlier spellings show that - it has developed from - ighte , or - ichte , i . e . the suffix has been generalised from the verbs having Ir . - ughadh , Sc . G . - achadh in the verbal noun , but does not necessarily imply the previous existence of such verbs .

1904 mar bhrāighid orainde :
‘ to be our pledge ’ ; according to CIL s . v . brage the - a - is short , but Dinneen gives “ braighe , also bráighe ” . The long vowel occurs in CIL s . v . bráge “ neck ” , Dinneen brágha , and dat . pl . brāighdibh above 930 . There seems to be some confusion between the two words , so that TSh glossary has brágha ( a ) “ neck ” , ( b ) “ captive ” , with - a - short in ( b ) , but also in some of the ( a ) quotations . Through the sense of “ captive ” and “ hostage ” the meaning “ security ” develops .

1924 do - chuaidh sē suas … a bfiadhnuise tsúl daoine :
‘ he visibly ascended to the heavens and was taken from the eyes of men ’ , where Carswell omits “ and was taken from ” and substitutes “ in the presence of ” .

1930 do fosgladh teaghduis Dē dhúinn :
‘ the heavens are opened to us ’ ; teaghdhuis “ dwelling - place ” here has the etymological spelling ( cf . CDIL s . v . tegdais ) , but in the remaining occurrences - dh - is dropped , e . g . 2665 , and , with a length - mark introduced , 3258 .

1931 as a bfēdfam :
apparently the relative form of the preposition as , “ out of which ” , referring to slighe ,
though there seems to be no ground for preferring as a to ina or ar a here . If an emendation is to be made , as go is the easiest .

1938 dār gcoimhéd agas dār gcoimh - dhīdean :
‘ as well to instruct us as to comfort and maintain us ’ , where Carswell omits the first verb .

1964 nō lá an ath - nuadhaidh :
an addition by Carswell . The reference is to Acts 3 . 19 .

1978 arna gcumailt :
‘ sprinkled ’ ; cf . CC 90 b 3 and note 328 b 7 . At 2612 below the meaning is “ apply ( a medicament ) ” .

1992 ré slāineōchar amhāin sind :
‘ by whom only we are sanctified ’ , but Carswell has “ shall be saved ” .

1995 agas go mbia and Eagluis :
‘ and shall be , even till the coming of the Lord Jesus , a Church ’ ; Carswell omits the adverbial phrase .

1997 ar son gur ghabh sī :
‘ because it receiveth ’ , but Carswell has “ has received ” .

2011 uilidhe nó chatharrdha :
‘ universal ’ ; uilidhe has been used in this sense at 1996 ; catharrdha is the adjective from cathair “ city ” , whence the use of it to render bellum ciuile in the title of the text Cath Cathardha .
Dwelly gives an creideamh catharra as “ the Reformed ( Protestant ) religion ” , but also an Eaglais ch .
as “ the Church militant , ” where catharra seems to be associated with cath .
The term “ universal ” was preferred by the reformers to “ catholic ” as restoring and clarifying the meaning of the latter . Despite the comprehensive definition in the following phrase , ‘ because it consisteth and standeth of all tongues and nations ; yea , of all estates and conditions of men and women ’ , the use of Book of the Universal Kirk as an alternative title for the record of the acts and proceedings of the General Assembly shows that it could also be applied to the Church as a whole within one state , in contrast to the individual congregation .

2031 macnas meanman :
‘ an imagination ’ , i . e . “ an illusion ” , from macnas “ sport , play ” , and meanma “ mind ” ; the phrase occurs again in CC 149 b 7 , but CDIL s . v . macnas has no other examples .

2033 a chorp féin :
‘ in his own body ’ ; therefore probably for
’ na chorp .
The reading a chorp may clarify én - chorp ar son chuirp eile ,
i . e . that the resurrected body is not a replacement of the earthly body by another , but in that case no question of deserving the same body can arise ; the reference here is clearly to 2 Cor . 5 . 10 chum gu faigh gach neach na nithe a rinn e sa choluinn a réir an ni a rinn e , ma ’ s maith no olc e .

2038 biaid :
this might be 3rd . per . pl . future , though the only example is beid 1234 , and the pl . would be unusual even if Carswell had had gach uile ghlóir agas onóir like his original . The simplest correction is to biaidh ,
but to correspond to the English we require bīodh ;
cf . 2867 note .

2050 neoch atāmuid do bhaisdeadh :
‘ whom we shall baptise ’ ; similarly neoch atāmuid do thabhairt mar ofrāil 2094 ‘ whom we offer ’ , which shows that do is not being used to convey futurity ( like English “ are to baptise ” ) , but is equivalent to ag .
Cf . notes 215 , 849 , 1024 .

2057 don bheatha - sa :
cf . note 1286 for beatha as gen . ; there seem to be no other examples of its use as dat . in place of the usual beathaidh .

2075 sinde do bheathughadh :
‘ beautify and bless us ’ , but Carswell prefers the more mundane “ nourish us ” .

2076 agas :
‘ but ’ , but Carswell does not follow the ‘ not only … but also ’ exactly , and has “ inasmuch as thou art not content … with feeding us … and in addition … increasest in us … as our bounden duty we lift up… ” . Cf . 2905 - 8 .

2111 mar is in - dēnta :
GB states that the monthly Communion is a common or general practice , but Carswell ’ s wording would make it mandatory . Calvin had wished for weekly Communion , but had been obliged to content himself with this monthly celebration , which accordingly appears here taken over from the Genevan practice . The Book of Discipline , however , has “ four times in the year we think sufficient to the administration of the Lord ’ s Table ” ( Laing II 239 ) , and this was formally enacted by the fifth General Assembly in December 1562 for the burghs , but “ twice in the year in country parishes ” ( Calderwood II 209 ) .

2117 1 Cor . 11 . 23 - 29 . The Irish Prayerbook version , f . Aa , the Epistle for Thursday before Easter , runs : Oír ios ón dtighearna fuáir meisi a ní thug mé dhíbhse mar an gcéudna , [eadhón] gur ghlac an tighearna Iosa arán sa noidhche ionar braitheadh hé : & ar mbreith bhuidheachais dó , do bhris sé [hé , ] 7 a dubhairt sé , glacaidh , ithidh : a sé só mo chorpsa brisdear ar bhur sonsa : déunaidh so mar choimhniughadh oramsa . Mar an gcéudna fós [do ghlac sé] an copán , tar éis shuipéir , agá rádh , a sé an cupasa an tiomna nuá , trém fhuilse : déunaidh so dhá mhioncachd iobhtháoi [hé , ] mar choimhniughadh oramsa . Oír ní fhuil dá mhionca iósas sibh an taránsa , 7 ióbhas sibh an cupasa , nách foillsigheann sibh bás an tighearna , gu teachd dó . Uime sin giodh bé iósas an taránsa , nó ióbhas cupá an tighearna gu neamhiomchuibhghe , biáidh sé cionntach dho chorp 7 dfhuil an tighearna . Ar a nadhbharsin dearbhadh gach áonduine hé féin , 7 mar sin itheadh sé dho naránsa , 7 ibheadh dhon chupasa . Oír giodh bé itheas 7 ibheas gu neamhiomchuibhghe , ithidh agus ibhidh sé do chum a dhamnuighthe féin , an tan nach déin eidirdhealughadh eidir chorp an tighearna [7 bhiádh eile . ]

2123 brisfidhear :
‘ which is broken ’ , as brisdear in the Irish version above ; Carswell uses the future as referring to events still to come when the words are spoken .

2128 īosas :
also 2131 , and in the Irish version above ; the rel . s - future of ithe ,
3rd . pers . sg . īosaidh 2137 . Cf . GOI § 658 ( a ) , CDIL s . v . ithid 326 . 46 and . 73 , and note in TSh glossary s . v . ithim the forms with - f - added to the íos - stem . Generally speaking , however , Carswell prefers caitheamh for “ eat ” , e . g . 2122 , 2148 , 2152 - 8 , 2222 , 3308 .

2130 do bhreith bhreithe ar bheōuibh agas ar mharbhaibh :
cf . the Creed 1154 ; Carswell adds these words to explain the purpose of the second coming .

2147 sul do rachas sé :
cf . sul do sgrībhadh 65 , sul sgaoilfeas siad 740 ; the former has do belonging to the verb , the latter shows the use of the relative after this conjunction . The other examples add only lenition of the verb as sol chaithid 3308 . For sul cf . CC 162 b 7 note . In this instance do may go with the verb , i . e . do - rachas as fut . rel . of MIr do - tét “ comes ” ( CDIL s . v . 379 . 16 - 30 ) , or it may be an early instance of do , perhaps pronounced only as a , as a relative particle , as in the Shorter Catechism ( CC xxxvii ) . Professor R . A . Breatnach refers ( Eriu XVII 104 ) to the form sula , with - a possibly modelled on muna , or to be identified with the preposition i . In this particular example we could assume that Carswell said sula and wrote sul do as a false etymological spelling , but elsewhere he has only the classical sul .

2161 ag brosnughadh dhīoghaltais do dhēnamh oraind :
‘ provoke him to plague us ’ , but Carswell has “ provoking the inflicting of punishment upon us ” .

2176 gan a chroidhe do bheith ag én - duine … teacht :
“ that no one [of these we have mentioned] have the presumption to come ” ; a is probably , the reduced form of do in a partitive sense . The pejorative extension , whereby “ heart ” in the sense of “ courage ” passes over into “ boldness , presumptuousness , obduracy ” seems to be Sc . G . rather than Irish .

2185 agā bfuil súil ré :
‘ who aspire to ’ ; cf . ní fhuil mo tsúil ré slánughadh do thaobh ele 3316 “ I hope for salvation from no other quarter ” , and CDIL s . v . súil II for the sense “ hope , expectation ” .
Dinneen treats this as a distinct word from súil “ eye ” , but this is unnecessary .

2207 lucht cathuighe :
apparently “ fighters ” , possibly with reference to 2202 , but in the context some such sense as “ partakers ” would be more appropriate ( the English has no noun at all ) , and we might read lucht cuidighe as at 2220 .

2210
’ nar mbeathuigheadh :
‘ in our lives ’ , but the Gaelic has a sg . noun , apparently not distinct from beathughadh ,
perhaps with the meaning “ living , manner of life ” ; the gen . beathuighe 2212 also corresponds to ‘ life ’ , perhaps with the sense “ quickening , enlivening ” rather than “ feeding , nourishing ” , though the latter is also appropriate in the context .

2214ff . In these lines I have followed the sentence division of 1567 , as Carswell may have intended to change the construction ; the English suggests rather that the first sentence should end with na h - Eagluise 2220 , and that ōir asē sin … a fhola 2221 - 2 should be placed in brackets , so that nā fuilghemaoid is construed as an imperative , not , as the other punctuation implies , a noun clause explaining the caitheamh fīrindeach .
This change , however , is incomplete unless we also add dhúinn after ar mbeith in 2220 .

2222 nā fuilghemaoid :
‘ let us not suffer ’ , or , in the original punctuation “ that we do not allow ” ; we expect fuilngemaoid ,
but note in DIL s . v . fo - loing 277 . 12 the possibility of confusion with fo - luigi , which has MIr stem foilgh - .

2231 do ghabhāil na h - oileamhna saoire agas na beathadh subsdaintighe - se :
‘ to receive nourishment , relief , and quickening of his substance ’ , but the Gaelic is “ to receive this free nourishment and substantial life ” ( or possibly “ food ” , though ‘ quickening ’ favours the former ) ; but cf . tug tú dhūinn fós mar oileamhain agas mar bheathaidh ‘ and hast given him unto us as … food and nourishment ’ 2314 .

2235 a bflaitheamhnus Dé :
‘ into heaven ’ ; cf . a bflaitheamhnus 2059 “ in heaven ” , where the transition from “ kingdom ” via “ kingdom of God ” ( as here ) to “ heaven ” is complete , as it is in Manx flaunys , which has no other meaning .

2264 do sgrios an fhir dob adhbhar don bhás :
‘ to destroy him that was author of death ’ ; the English points to údhdar ( as at 3493 ) as a likely correction of the original adhar ,
but the correction

2270 a ghabhāil cuige :
‘ to comprehend ’ ; elsewhere in the text the forms of this pronominal preposition are permanently lenited so that cuige is probably only a misprint .

2274 an uair nārbh aithnidh dúinn :
‘ when we could do nothing ’ ; Carswell has already used aithnidh in the usual sense of “ known ” 356 , 1419 , but from here on he uses it several times as “ possible ” , e . g . gurab aithnidh dhuid féin gach én - ní ar a bfuil a fheidhm nō a fhurtacht do fhreasdal dó 2617 ‘ and thou canst … minister unto him all such things as shall be necessary and expedient . ’ Similarly 2668 - 81 , 2975 . This sense is not recognised in CDIL s . v . 3 aithnid , but the development from “ known , familiar ” is understandable . Cf . Des . 5894 for the phrase da ttuguinn dó an moladh as mó as aithnidh dhamh 7 as éidir leam , though it is by no means certain that aithnidh and éidir are meant to be synonymous .

2288 maille rē bfuil ar gcoinbhearsáid - ne go sdrāsda ar neamh :
‘ with whom we have our conversation presently in heaven ’ ; I supply coinbhearsáid from the Irish Prayerbook , f . Qq 2 , the Epistle for Trinity XXIII : Achd as ar neamh atá ar gcoinbhearsáidne , an tionadh as a bhfuil súil aguinn fós ré teachd an tslanaighthóra , Philippians 3 . 20 , one of the passages referred to in the marginal notes of GB . The word - division go sdrāsda follows the original edition , though the normal writing would be either in one word or trásda as the second ; as trásda is an old metathesis of tráth - sa ( before th ceased to be a voiceless dental spirant ) the whole means “ till this time , hitherto , already ” .

2306 mar do bhādar na cédfadha :
“ as the senses were … ” ; the past tense is peculiar as the context is present . Carswell has shortened the original rubric here : ‘ During the which time , some place of the Scriptures is read , which doth lively set forth the death of Christ , to the intent that our eyes and senses may not only be occupied in these outward signs of bread and wine , which are called the visible word , but that our hearts and minds also may be fully fixed in the contemplation of the Lord ’ s death , which is by this holy Sacrament represented . ’

2314 mar bheathaidh in - mholta do chum na beathadh suthaine :
‘ as a necessary … nourishment unto everlasting life ’ ; but in -

mholta , from moladh ,
is elsewhere “ laudable , praiseworthy ” , e . g . 684 . A simple emendation would be in - mhelta from mealaim “ use , consume , enjoy ” , for which see CDIL s . v . meilid II , and Shorter Catechism ( CC p . 233 ) .

2336 trí lá tsaoire :
‘ three several days ’ , but lá saoire is really a day free from labour , a holy - day or holiday ( cf . cuimhnidh lá na Sabbōide do chongbhāil a saoire 3444 , ’ na lá saoire 3476 ) ; with the abolition of the feast - days the term became synonymous with Sunday . Cf . CDIL s . v . 1 saíre Ia and III .

2343 The exhortation and the question put to the parties to be married ( 2406 - 17 ) are similar to passages in the First and Second Prayerbooks of Edward VI , but the exhortation is considerably expanded . With 2344 - 50 cf . Irish Prayer Book , f . NNn verso : A cháirde ró ghrádhacha , tangamair a gceand a chéile a bhfhíaghnaise Dé , agus do láithir a Eágailsi , chum na lánamhnachso do cheangal dá chéile andsa fphósadh náomhtha : Gárub sdaid onórach hé , dho orduigh Día a Bfháirchios , sul do fpheacthaibh [sic] Adhamh .

2356
’ na uathadh nō ’ na ēnar :
‘ alone ’ ; for this use of uathadh “ small number ” see CDIL s . v . úathad 42 . 39 .

2415 bhur gceangal … nach bfuiltí ceangailte :
the introduction of the 2nd pers . is Carswell ’ s .

2421 nach gcluinim … ar pósadh do dhēnamh :
added by Carswell to explain what the congregation is being invited to bear witness to .

2470 sgaraidh duine rēna athair agas rēna mhāthair :
‘ a man shall leave father and mother ’ ; cf . 2363 where the same phrase renders ‘ leaveth his father and mother ’ . “ Shall ” here is the mark of custom or obligation rather than of futurity , and the present is a perfectly admissible rendering . This passage is quoted in ID 131 as an example of the Sc . G . use of present for future , but there are better examples in Carswell , for which see the Introduction .

2511 dá rabh uireasbhuidh riachtanais a leas ar an easlān :
‘ if he perceive him to want any necessaries ’ ; cf . note 120 . The phrase is used here in the concrete sense of “ something needed ” , for which see CDIL s . v . riachtanas ( b ) ; for the abstract sense , “ need , lack ” , cf . 3079 .

2512 cungnamh leis :
‘ he … relieveth him ’ ; so spelt at 3003 , but also congnamh 2712 . In GB 2500 - 15 is all one sentence , though with a capital letter at 2510 , and there is in the Gaelic a series of non - finite verbs , teagasg do thabhairt 2503 , bagar do dhēnamh 2507 , now cungnamh ,
and tabhairt 2513 , all depending on lēigmaoid … do chum tuigse an Mhinistir 2502 . The connection is nearly lost in the Gaelic and a 3rd . sg . imperative would have been clearer . It is , of course , possible that cungnamh is intended as an imperative ; cf . note 2744 .

2513 ar feadh a nearta nó a chumhachta :
‘ according to his ability ’ ; ar feadh is usually “ throughout ” and go feadh ,
“ to the limit of ” as at 44 , 3484 . There is no evidence for neart as a u - stem , so that nearta ( also at 3484 ) cannot be its gen . sg . , for which Carswell has neirt .
It is probably the gen . sg . of neartadh “ strengthen -
ing ” , which is occasionally used as a synonym of neart . Cf . gen . foirrnearta 1062 .

2515 dlighidh :
‘ may ’ , i . e . “ is entitled to ” , the less common sense .

2516 neoch do - ní guidhe … mar an gcēdna :
‘ who doth not only make prayers for him there presently , but also , if it so require , commendeth him in the public prayers to [of ? ] the congregation . ’

2535 gallradh :
‘ sickness ’ , but probably gen . pl . like the parallel easslāinteadh ;
hardly from galar ,
but probably an instance of galradh ,
of which CDIL G 41 . 3 records only one example .

2538 ag tabhairt tséla ar ndroch - bheatha dhúinn :
‘ advertising us of our evil life ’ , i . e . “ warning us ” ; séla elsewhere is “ seal ” , here “ a clear , authentic sign ” , almost “ a proof ” .

2569 indsuidhe imarcacha :
‘ assaults ’ ; historically spelt indsaighthe .

2593 atá tú anois agā fhios :
‘ thou now visitest him ’ ; for this sense of fios ,
parallel to fiosrughadh 2497 , 2519 , see DIL s . v . 1 fis I ( c ) .

2596 gé nach bfuil a theangaidh … aibēil :
‘ although the tongue be not able ’ ; cf . CDIL s . v . aipéil “ quick , sudden ” , while the derivatives aipéile “ quickness , flattery ” , and aipélugud “ adulation ” , are still further removed from the sense required here . The other examples in Carswell are atá do ghnáth ullamh ésgaidh aibēil 2765 ‘ ever in readiness ’ , and lé bfétar misi do dhenamh aibél do ghabháil thoraidh 3153 ‘ the which may make me able so to profit ’ ; that at 2765 may very well be taken as “ swift ” , but the other two are more naturally understood as “ able ” . CDIL 162 . 65 says “ with influence of English able ” , assuming the Irish word has acquired a modified meaning from a similar English word ; it is equally probable that English able was already a current borrowing which Carswell identified in form with a native word . Early Manx had similarly borrowed it as abyl , and Irish as ábalta , with adaptation to the suffix of spesialta and the like .

2598 do fhoillseochadh :
formally the conditional , as at 1495 , and so with glóir acc . sg . , but BCO ’ s ‘ to set forth thy glory ’ suggests it should be the verbal noun and that accordingly we require glóire .
None of CDIL ’ s quotations under oific gives the construction which follows , but we expect either the gen . of the verbal noun ( excluded here because of a oifige “ its office ” ) , or do with the verbal noun , as in Des . 2520 - 22 , 3011 - 12 .

2599 ar a tson sin :
“ despite that , nevertheless ” , answering to gé nach bfuil 2596 . So perhaps at 1734 , and cf . CDIL s . v . 1 son II ( f ) .

2605 is ēidir lé nāmhaid ar n - anma … ar gcoinsiasa :
‘ which the enemy of our salvation may raise up to trouble his conscience ’ , but Carswell uses the 1st . pers . pl . throughout .

2623 a thriall agas a tslighe :
‘ his recourse and access ’ ; perhaps simply “ course and path ” , but cf . CDIL s . v . tríall ( b ) “ endeavour , purpose ” , and especially the last quotation , do eisd in Tigherna trial ocus iniaratus na mbocht from Smaointe B . Chr . 2610 , rendering desiderium pauperum exaudiuit Dominus ( Psalm 10 . 17 ) . See note 2811 .

2637 dó ina uile pheacthuibh … go bfuighe sé maitheamh … :
‘ to all sinners , to obtain remission of all their sins ’ ; Carswell here ( cf . 2605 ) applies the general statement particularly to the sick man . He also adds an explanatory do bhrīdh a dhóchais as 2640 “ because of his confidence in him ” .

2645 tasdáil nua agas fēchain :
‘ a new taste of ; the original print has the unique sasdáil ,
and , although in its lenited forms this would not be distinct from the loan - word tástáil ( CDIL s . v . ) , for which there is only one example recorded , the correction seems certain , not least because foreign verbs tend to be assigned the - áil suffix .

2657 creidmhe :
an isolated form of the gen . of creideamh ,
for which Carswell normally has creidimh ,
as do CC and TSh . For this form cf . Des . 3423 , 4641 , where it is also the less frequent alternative .

2701 mur dhearrna tú … mun tuga tú … :
both mur and mun are “ unless ” , and are paralleled by the longer forms mura , mara and muna ( cf . 237 note , only muna in CC ) . Cf . R . A . Breatnach , Eriu XVII 104 “ mara … , which developed in the late modern period from muna [in the footnote he quotes seventeenth - century examples] , in all probability owes its form to the influence of gurab and nárab with which munab was associated in the subjunctive . ”

2729 tar éis ar dtrēigthe féin dúin :
‘ forsaking ourselves ’ ; the verbal noun is elsewhere trēigean ,
but this form of the gen . sg . goes rather with tréigeadh ,
cf . CDIL s . v . trécud . No gen . forms seem to be recorded but cf . the verbal of necessity tréigthe in TSh 2285 .

2741 gan ní ar bith eile do phrósession nó dh ’ ordughadh :
‘ without any further ceremonies ’ ; this meagre provision for funerals is

explained in the Book of Discipline ( Laing II 250 ) : “ for albeit thingis song and red may admonishe some of the levying to prepair thame selfis for death , yit shall some superstitious and ignorant personis ever think , that the workis synging or reading of the levyng do and may proffat the dead . ” And ibid . p . 251 : “ We are nott ignorant that some requyre ane Sermone at the Buriall , or ellis some places of Scripturis to be red , to put the leving in mynd that thei ar mortall , and that lykwyse thei must dye . ” If this demand were granted “ eather shall the Ministeris for the most parte be occupyed in preaching Funerall sermonis , or ellis thei shall have respect to personis , preaching at the buriall of the rich and honorabill , but keaping silence when the poore or dispysed departeth ; and this with saif conscience can not the Ministeris do . ” Carswell ’ s omission of the BCO ’ s words ‘ if he [the minister] be present and required ’ may be an attempt to provide that there should always be at least ‘ some comfortable exhortation ’ at funerals , but he may merely have been following GB at this point .

2744 dēnadh :
“ let him make ” . The original has denamh and similarly do dhenamh for do - dhēnadh ,
2842 ; denamh is so common that the compositor may have set it automatically , but it may also point to the phonetic identity of the two final syllables . This is better evidence that Carswell pronounced - adh in the same way as - amh ( see ID 69 ) than his spellings futhaibh beside futhadh ( cf . notes 1097 , 1277 ) , where another explanation is possible .

2754 óir is gloine í … uirre :
‘ which requireth more purely to be governed ’ , whereas Carswell has “ for it is purer and more proper to be governed ” .

2768 agā Eagluis , lé ndēnaid foghlaim… :
‘ left by God unto his church , whereby men learn … ’ ; the transition from sg . eagluis to the 3 pl . dēnaid seems rather harsher than is usual in this constructio ad sensum , and it may be that we should follow GB more closely and insert daoine .
Cf . , however , don Eagluis … gurab éigean dōibh … do ghabhāil chuca 2846 - 9 .

2776 áirfidhe :
see note 1332 .

2779 tearmond :
for the shift in meaning whereby Latin terminus came to be equivalent to “ sanctuary ” in Irish , cf . CDIL s . v . termonn .

2801 rún ro - leasaighthe :
“ intention of improvement ” ; ro - seems
to be purely for the sake of alliteration and not to have any intensive force . Similarly lucht luath - bhrisde th ’ aitheantadh 2999 .

2802 a bfiadhnuise deise nō trír d ’ fhiadhnuise maith :
‘ in presence of two or three witnesses ’ ; Carswell ’ s final phrase is perhaps predicative “ by way of reliable testimony ” . The absence of lenition in maith must be erroneous , for fiadhnuise even in the sense of “ a witness ” is f .

2811 ó tslighidh agas ó thoil mhaith :
‘ of a godly zeal ’ , where slighe must presumably mean “ purpose , intention ” , as the parallel triall seems to do at 2623 .

2836 fear ghabhāla ceandaigh a n - adhaidh na córa :
“ briber ” , which now suggests the offerer rather than the taker , but in NED s . v . Briber sense 3 “ a taker of bribes ” has quotations from 1520 to 1611 , while sense 4 “ a giver of bribes ” is first attested in 1583 .

2839 úsuruidhe :
‘ usurer ’ ; not in this form in CDIL , but cf . úsaire “ usurer ” , úsaracht “ usury ” , úsúrach “ usurious ” .

2840 lucht eiritice nó saobh - chreidimh nó droch - tsligheadh :
‘ any heresy or sect ’ ; eiritice is presumably gen . sg . of a noun “ heresy ” , but DIL has only eirice “ heretic ” , eiricecht and eiriticecht “ heresy ” , and eretic “ heretic ” and eretecda , - dach “ heretical ” . For droch - tslighe ,
cf . slighe 2941 and CDIL s . v . slige II ( e ) , where this sense is supported by a single quotation . The origin of this use of the word may be found in Acts 9 . 2 nam faigheadh e aon neach do ’ n t - slighe so ,
and again in chs . 19 and 24 .

2867 This sentence , Matthew 18 . 17 , is from BCO : biaidh renders let him be ’ ( cf . note 2038 for another case where bíodh would be a more exact translation ) . This passage provided DIL with its only example of éticeach ,
and it is possible that we should read étniceach ,
a borrowing of ethnicus ; cf . DIL s . v . etnic , and NED s . v . ethnic ( B ) n . “ a Gentile , heathen , pagan ” , recorded from c . 1375 to 1728 .

2880 do - nīmaoid ort :
‘ which we shall make to thee ’ ; the 1st .

pl . fut . would probably be written do - dhénam ,
but as the sense is iterative the present is equally appropriate .

2891 an ní lēr thuilleamar :
‘ whereby we deserve ’ , in which Carswell quite legitimately uses the perfect ; an ní is presumably meant to clarify the antecedent , and would be appropriate if it had been a clause , but rather obscures the connection with ar bpeacaidh .

2899 agas gach én - lá eile feadh ar mbeathadh :
“ and every other day throughout our life ” ; added by Carswell , who elsewhere has ar feadh .

2912 ar gcroidheadha d ’ fhoillsiudhadh :
‘ to lighten our hearts ’ ; see note 1402 .

2953 do mhēdughadh a dtīrēnacht agas a bfoirrnearta :
‘ to increase their tyranny ’ ; tīrēnacht has escaped the notice of CDIL , though tíránach ( and one example of tírēnach ) and tíránta are included .

2977 go h - umhal ómanta :
‘ humbly ’ ; ómanta ( also at 3172 ) is not noted in CDIL and there can hardly be any connection with its noun omántas . Cf . probably omoint ibid . 142 . 50 , if the meaning of the latter were more certain .

3025 agas go madh móide , a Thighearna , bhus toil leat sin d ’ admhāil , a fhaigsin duid … :
‘ and so much the rather , O Lord , because … ’ ; the words bhus toil leat sin d ’ admhāil “ may it please thee to admit it ” are Carswell ’ s own , but “ so much the more ” refers back to “ weigh ” ( go mbreathnōchamaois 3023 ) and “ repent ” ( go ndēnmaois aithrighe 3024 ) , i . e . we are to consider and repent of our sins all the more seriously when we consider the fate of those who fail to do so . Carswell ’ s rendering means something quite different . The construction in a fhaigsin duid ( which , in line with the thought of the English , should rather be dúinn ) is abnormal ; cf . note 919 .

3051 aislinge nó taibhsidhe nó sbiorada buaidheartha :
this prayer was evidently translated from BCO rather than GB , as the former has here ‘ fantasies , dreams , or other temptations ’ , while GB has ‘ temptations , fantasies , dreams , or illusions ’ .

3057 as go madh ullmhuide … sin :
“ that we may be the more ready to … ” ; cf . note 1447 .

3059 a n - āmhaillibh agas a dtrēighibh diadha :
‘ in all godly conversation ’ , i . e . “ behaviour , manner of life ” ; for tréidhe ,
correctly so spelt , see CDIL s . v . tréide I “ set of three , triad ” , and then , apparently because of triadic enumerations of good qualities , II “ accomplishments , characteristics , qualities ” .

3065 adhmoladh :
printed ádh - , and similarly ágh - 3653 , 3860 ; for the lengthening see Celtica I 340 .

3082 ar son ar bfulaing a bfad d ’ aimsir :
‘ for sparing us so long ’ .

3083 ag tabhairt aimsire faide :
‘ giving so large a time ’ ; fada here forms a gen . f . sg . faide like the comparative .

3100 mēdaidh … agas cuir a leithead do Rīghacht :
‘ amplify and increase thy Kingdom ’ .

3116 a n - umhlu agas a n - onōrudh th ’ anma naomhtha - sa :
‘ in the sanctifying and honour of thine holy Name ’ ; the Gaelic is rather “ in the obedience and honouring … ” , assuming that umhlu is for umhla . Onōrudh is probably onóradh ,
cf . frithōlugh 3358 , and CDIL s . v . onóraid . O ’ Rahilly notes ( ID 67 - 8 ) that - ughadh has been for at least three centuries reduced to - ú in Irish , but it would be contrary to the whole character of Carswell ’ s spelling to assume that he intended umhlú and onórú here .

3146 lé toil thindeasnaidh :
cf . tindeanas “ haste ” 1676 , from which this adjective is derived . CDIL s . v . tinnesnach gives “ hurried , urgent , violent , sudden ” , but Carswell is using it rather for “ eager ” .

3147 iondas nach rachadh mo tsaothar a ndolaidh oram :
“ lest my labour should be wasted ( to my loss ) ” ; for dolaidh see CDIL s . v . dolud , the antonym of soladh , solaidh “ good fortune ” . The expression dul a ndolaidh ‘ be wasted , come to naught ’ is not recorded . Cf . dul
a ndīomhaoineas 3155 with similar meaning , and , with a different preposition , Sc . G . dol a dholaidh .

3156 ge bé h - aigneadh ar a dtiubhra mé aire :
‘ to what study soever I apply myself ’ , i . e . “ to whatever subject I give my attention ” ; this is a rare sense of aigneadh ,
for which cf . CDIL s . v . 1 aicned ( e ) “ knowledge , science ” . Des . 6449 may have something of the same sense , but the context there is not very explicit .

3180 Na tiodhluice … :
added by Carswell ; “ these gifts and every other good gift I ask of thee , O merciful Father , in the name of thy Son Jesus Christ , as he himself has taught me saying , Our Father , etc . ”

3185 Psalm 25 . 14 . Foillseōchaidh … do - bhēra … :
both future , though the English has present tenses .

3191 aithne :
probably for a aithne as at 1583 , 2920 , where a noun clause follows to which a refers .

3192 atāmaoid ag eadar - ghuidhe do ghrás :
but ‘ we beseech thee of thy grace ’ .

3194 as go soitheōchadh an beandachadh - sin :
‘ that thy blessing may extend ’ ; the - th - spelling is also found in go soithe “ until ” 1410 , 1924 , literally “ until thou reach ” , 2nd . sg . pres . subj . of 1 saigid ( cf CDIL s . v . ) , for - ch - , and in a number of other words , for which see note 767 . The basis for an - eó - conditional in this verb is obscure to me ; emendation to bfaideóchadh ( cf . CC 217 b 5 . 2 ) would be drastic .

3271 d ’ iumchor chroiche éigne :
‘ to suffer some cross ’ ; for iumchur cf . note 1713 . For éigin “ some ” cf . DIL s . v . éicin II , originally the dat sg . of éicen ( = éigean ) , and so invariable . Carswell here treats it as an ordinary adjective and forms a regular gen . f . sg .

3277 ina ghlōir :
“ in his glory ” placed by Carswell as if to refer

3284 a thoile :
but ‘ thy will ’ in GB .

3312 An Maighistir :
but ‘ The Minister ’ ; and 3314 An Descibul ,
but ‘ The Child ’ .

3337 Ciondas ele :
not “ how else ” , but “ how , then ” ; cf . créd eile 3352 “ what , then ” , and 3413 , 3505 , but “ what else ” at 3385 .

3430 For other versions of the Commandments cf . CC 217 b , taken from the Irish Prayer Book , f . LLL 2 verso ( also at CCc 2 verso ) , and Shorter Catechism ( CC p . 248 ) . The Shorter Catechism version clearly owes much to Carswell ’ s , the only differences between them being the result of slight modernisation of some expressions : thus agā mbia m ’ fhuath 3439 and agā mbia mo ghrádh 3440 become fhuathuigheas me and ghradhuigheas me ,
and the future fhoillseōchas 3439 becomes fhoillsidheas ; do chongbhāil a saoire 3444 ( see note 2336 ) becomes a chonbhail no a choimhed naomhtha ;
the sequence of imperatives in 3447 - 8 is simplified ; an taisteallach bhias taoibh astoigh dod t ’ árus 3449 becomes en duine coimheach ata don taobh a stoigh dod dhoirsibh ; gach ní dhā bfuil inta sin 3452 becomes gach ni ata ionta ; an Sathurn ( see note below ) 3454 becomes an Tsaboid ; iondas go 3455 becomes chum go ( which Carswell also uses ) , and the future do - bhéra 3456 becomes do bheir ; dēna 3457 - 8 becomes den ; adhaltrus 3457 becomes adhaltrannus ( which Carswell also uses ) ; the regular neutral gen . sg . of the consonant stem comharsand 3459 - 60 gives way to a palatal comharsoin ,
- ain , while the palatal dat . sg . cumhursaind 3462 becomes neutral comharsan ; a bhó 3461 becomes a dhamh .
Apart from the replacement of non - popular

3432 íomhaigh ghrafinte :
“ graven image ” ; cf . SC ( CC , p . 248 ) iomhaigh ghraifne ,
CC 143 b 1 grafaint ,
and the verbal noun grafadh 339 a 5 , parallel to cur a gclo ( though it is also used as a loan form of English graf ( t ) ; see CC 184 b 2 note ) . The Irish versions do not translate “ graven ” at all , and the expression renders a single Hebrew word . Though CDIL has several similar terms for “ writing , sketching , grubbing up ” , there are no exact parallels to any of these . The Irish OT uses grabhálta , and later greannta .

3446 Sathurn :
and also at 3454 . The Jewish Sabbath , of course , falls on Saturday , so that Carswell is historically correct in using Sabbōid and Sathurn as synonyms . The reflexes of sabbatum or dies sabbati remain the ordinary Romance terms for “ Saturday ” , but it is dies Saturni that provides the basis of the Celtic and English names . Carswell was obviously unaffected by the tendency to identify the Sabbath of the old dispensation with the Sunday or Lord ’ s Day of the new , a tendency which became common only in the seventeenth century . Cf . below 3548 - 60 .

3461 a bhó :
now “ his ox ” , but the Hebrew word , normally “ ox ” , is twice found in a context where it must refer to a female and accordingly is translated “ cow ” .

3466 roindfead :
“ I shall divide ” ; the only instance in Carswell of the inflected 1st . sg . fut .

3473 gan deilbh do dhēnamh :
“ not to make any image ” ; cf . Des . p . 272 , where examples of both nom . and acc . after gan in this construction are collected . Deilbh is properly speaking acc . or dat .

sg . of dealbh ,
( gen . sg . deilbhe 1065 ) , but at 3511 we have deilbh fhīrindeach as nom . sg . Since dealbh is not attested at all in Carswell we may assume that he uses only deilbh as nom . , as below 3491 , 3513 .

3495 agas gur ghnáthach :
cf . agas gurab suarraighe iad 3534 for go introducing a formally subordinate clause which has on main clause on which to depend . The meaning of agas go in both cases is “ seeing that ” , as with the formally non - subordinate agas é a n - aitheantaibh Dé 3516 and similarly 3606 .

3539 luigheas lámha nó uaisle nó cumhachta rīogh nó tighearna :
note the direct objects after luighe ,
instead of the prepositions tar and fo .
Similarly Dinneen has mionnuighim an bhacall “ I swear by the crozier ” .

3558
’ na suaine suthain :
“ as a perpetual … ” ; suaine is obscure . M ’ L took it as from suan and so translated “ rest ” ; Professor Matheson was considering a connection with suaitheantus or the like and proposed the translation “ symbol ” . In that case the spelling should rather be suaithne ,
from so + aithne “ a thing easily recognised ” , with the general meaning “ sign ” .

3577 orraim :
“ respect ” ; see CDIL s . v . airraim , with variants uirrim ( so TSh ) , oirrim , urraim . Similarly paired with onóir 3802 .

3650 bhéras tú :
“ will you give ” makes good sense , though “ do you give ” is perhaps better . The form is irregular , combining as it does the sense “ give ” with the absence of do - , and - é - of the future with the relative ending - as ( cf . do - bhéra “ which he shall give ” 3456 ) .

3656 do dhórtadh orra :
we should expect either mar dob áil lé Dia … orra “ as it has pleased God to pour out his graces upon them ” , or possibly the present or future ( is áil , bhus áil ) , followed by oram “ upon me ” . Carswell ’ s expression is , however , defensible if “ saints ” is to be understood in the NT sense , but the context makes this unlikely .

3675 Caidh é :
similarly 3705 , and Des . caidhe , caidhi , but written as one word and without length - mark . Meyer tentatively suggested OIr cote , pl . coteet , as the origin , for which see GOI § 462 , but there is a discrepancy between OIr - t - ( = d ) and MIr - d - ( = dh ) . Dr E . G . Quin discusses the problems in Eriu xx 140 - 150 , though without including these examples . He accepts OIr cote as the origin of both caidhe ,
stressed on the first syllable , and modern Sc . G . gu dé ,
and suggests “ a dialectal split going a long way back in the history

3684 sa chánoin ina dtuigmaoid féin é :
similarly
’ na gcanóin choimhidhigh nach dtuigeand an pobul … acht sa chanóin choitchind thuigfeas an coimthionōl 3754 - 6 . M ’ L translated canóin as “ language ” and this is supported by the reference in all three places to understanding ; the form of the word corresponds to that used for “ canon ” . If the latter were correct “ canon ” would have to have the generalised sense of “ prescribed method ” of prayer or administering the sacraments , and would imply that not only the language but the form of the ceremonies obscured their meaning and purpose . While the reformers would probably have agreed with this , though regarding it as an understatement , the assumption that canóin is a vernacular variant of canamhain ( cf . note 230 ) , in line with the generally simpler language of the catechism , remains more probable .

3687 Scriphtūir :
an isolated spelling , probably to be corrected to Scribhtūir .

3733 briathra Dé do tsearmóin :
and similarly lē searmōin bhriathar nDé 3734 ; for other examples of searmóin as a verbal noun cf . CDIL s . v . sermóin 192 . 60 .

3741 rún umhla … aca :
although the noun umhla seems possible the adjective umhal would be better here , “ and having a humble desire ( or , intention ) of having him baptised ” .

3771 na suibhiscēul :
“ of the evangelists ” ; cf . CDIL s . v . suibiscél , and CC suighscel 368 b 4 ( also gen . pl . ) .

3779 agas :
perhaps better acht ,
as it stands between one point of difference and one of similarity .

3786 - 9 Ní fhuil sé mar sin and … acht gé tá sé go spioratālta lēna chumhachtaibh :
“ He is not so present … although he is spiritually [present] by his power ” ; the second “ present ” may be understood from the first , or and sin or do láthair may be supplied after sé .

3827 - 35 From BCO : the first ‘ thanksgiving before meat ’ is passed over ; 3828 - 35 represents the second : the verses from Psalm 145 . 15 , 16 , and ‘ Good Lord , bless us and the gifts which we receive of thy large liberality through Jesus Christ our Lord . So be it . Our Father , &c . ’

3849 - 61 BCO ’ s first ‘ thanksgiving before meat ’ abridged : ‘ Eternal and everlasting God , Father of our Lord Jesus Christ , who of thy most singular love which thou bearest to mankind , hast appointed to his sustenance not only the fruits of the earth , but also the fowls of the air , and beasts of the earth , and fishes of the sea , and hast commanded thy benefits to be received as from thine hands with thanksgiving , assuring thy children by the mouth of thine Apostle , that to the clean all things are clean , as the creatures which be sanctified by the word and by prayer ; grant unto us so moderately to use these thy gifts present , that the bodies being refreshed , the souls may be more able to proceed in all good works , to the praise of thine holy Name , through Jesus Christ our Lord . So be it . Our Father which art , &c . ’

3859 umhal do ghluasacht :
‘ more able to proceed ’ ; but the sense of “ ready , willing ” is more usually conveyed by Carswell by using ullamh .

3900 do chum chuain agas chalaidh : cuan here in the old sense of “ harbour ” , as shown by the parallel caladh ,
not in the Sc . G . and Manx sense of “ sea ” .

3904 On the poem cf . also CC p . 220 . The English metrical psalms gave rise to similar metrical versions of the Prayerbook canticles and of the Lord ’ s Prayer and Commandments , and similarly in the 1575 edition of BCO the Lord ’ s Prayer and the Ten Commandments ( for a version of which see CC p . 221 - 3 ) followed the metrical psalms . With the phrase a meadarthacht dhána ( copied into CC iv ) cf . CC i ina meadardhachd ,
and the Caogad ’ s a meadrachd Gaoidhilg and the Metrical Psalms ( 1694 ) a meadar dhana Gaoidheilg .

3917 Beatha na h - anma ’ s an chuirp :
printed sa chuirp ,
an early example of the loss of - n in the article before lenited consonants .

3920 gan dlaoi gan dáil :
both phrases are present primarily for metrical reasons ; dáil “ delay , hesitation ” is clear enough , but on dlaoi see CDIL s . v . dlaí . None of the meanings given there is very suitable and this example is not quoted ; perhaps some further development of sense ( b ) fig . “ screen , shelter ” towards “ obstacle ” would fit . Professor Matheson suggested “ without stint ” .

3927 a mbuaidhridh lind :
Professor Matheson hesitated between this reading and ar mbuaidhridh ,
rendering “ aid us against our temptations ( ? ) ” , i . e . taking lind with bí .
It would be more natural to take lind with buaidhreadh ,
but then with ar we should need to have leó ,
i . e . “ oppose our being troubled by them ” ( sc . ar náimhde ) , which is forbidden by the metre . If we leave the text alone we must assume buaidhreadh lé ,
“ oppose their troubling us ” , which fits rather better with ar a n - iocht “ at their mercy ” .

3935 go ndénaid … sgige :
the sense seems certainly future “ will ridicule ” , i . e . when it comes into their hands , but - dénaid is formally present , and Carswell has no examples of the dependent future stem diongn - at all ( cf . CC le ndiongantar 126 b 7 ) . Similarly at 3944 .

3938 cruas :
“ hardness ” , but as a laudatory stylistic term not “ obscurity ” but “ vigour , firmness ” . Professor Matheson suggests “ precision ” .

3939 foclōracht :
the word is not noted in DIL , nor is foclóir ,
which occurs in Lhuyd as “ a vocabulary ” ; Carswell ’ s word may be an earlier attempt at creating a term with this meaning , or , assuming an unrecorded foclóir , he may have wished to distinguish between “ a vocabulary ” and “ vocabulary ” . The sentence seems to refer to ( a ) deficiencies in his vocabulary or command of appropriate terms , ( b ) want of correctness in writing , i . e . presumably in spelling , and ( c ) misprints , which are not entirely his own responsibility . In the last phrase litre appears to be gen . sg . dependent on uireasbhuidh like fhoclōrachta and chearta ;
the sense might be clearer if we read liter a n - inadh litre ele “ one letter in place of another ” . The pl . litre a n - inadh litreadh ele is also possible . For litear ,
not litir ,
see IGT Decl . § 54 .

3942 do thuairim :
cf . CDIL s . v . túaraim , where there is no exact parallel to this phrase . The alternative do bharamhail is “ by guess ” , and so probably here “ by likelihood ” , with reference to the compositor ’ s having guessed at the likeliest interpretation of the ambiguities of Carswell ’ s handwriting .

3971 - 2 This couplet comes from a poem by Fearghal mac Domhnuill Ruaidh mac an Bhaird , published as no . 48 in his Dioghluim Dána by Fr . MacKenna , stanza 28cd . It is cited in IGT Decl . § 74 , line 1572 , for the dat . sg . cronn . The poem begins Olc íocthar ar luagh leighis . Professor Matheson translates : He has put

with this spear of the breast a protecting hoop round the blood of Eve . For cíoch , cíogh m . , with gen . sg . cíogha ,
see IGT Decl . § 46 .
